snippet.title: New law creates stiffer penalties for unsecured loads on roadways
snippet.description:
Utah is known for its beauty, but anyone who has driven on its roads for long enough knows the pain of things like a crack in the windshield from something hitting it.

Sometimes, however, it's more serious than a crack.

State officials and law enforcement are calling unsecured loads and debris in the road a problem, and earlier this year, a law was passed to give Utah Highway Patrol the ability to combat it.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/local/new-law-creates-stiffer-penalties-for-unsecured-loads-on-roadways

snippet.title: North Salt Lake doesn't rule out legal challenge over new homeless campus
snippet.description:
The city of North Salt Lake said it has compassion for the homeless and wants to work with the state on solutions for the unsheltered.

On Thursday, however, the city manager would not rule out a legal challenge over the selected site for a new 1,300-bed campus for the homeless.

"That would be a decision made by our elected officials," said Ken Leetham, city manager. "I can't rule that out."

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/local/north-salt-lake-doesnt-rule-out-legal-challenge-over-new-homeless-campus

snippet.title: Judge asserts Tyler Robinson should attend hearings in person regardless of media attention
snippet.description:
Fourth District Court Judge Tony Graf reminded attorneys that Tyler Robinson, the man accused of killing Charlie Kirk, is presumed innocent and that he won't put his “finger on the scale of justice.”

A status conference was scheduled for October 20 at 10 a.m. Judge Graf said Robinson was expected to be present for that hearing.

“It is the standing order of this court that Mr. Robinson shall be allowed to appear in person so he can fully engage with his attorneys and participate in these legal proceedings,” Graf said.

Tyler Robinson attended the past hearings virtually from jail.

MORE: https://kutv.com/news/local/lead-defense-attorney-appointed-for-tyler-robinson-in-charlie-kirk-assassination-case

snippet.title: How to disagree better
snippet.description:
Disagreements happen but they don't need to lead to shouting or violence. There are ways to have a good conversation with differing opinions.

Utah State professor David Schramm joined ARC Salt Lake to discuss a program he helped set up at Utah State called, "Disagree Better" with the hope of teaching people how to have a good conversation without it escalating.

snippet.title: Father of three fights for life after serious motorcycle crash
snippet.description:
A father of three is fighting for his life after a serious motorcycle crash.

According to officers with the West Valley City Police Department, a vehicle did an improper U-turn in front of Jon Lackey last Thursday, which caused the crash.

His family is now holding their breath as doctors try to save his life at Intermountain Hospital in Murray.

snippet.title: "The Gospel for America":Carlson's message at Kirk's memorial service
snippet.description:
Former TV personality Tucker Carlson talked about assassinated political activist Charlie Kirk's faith and fight at Kirk's memorial service in Arizona. 

The public memorial service and funeral for political activist Charlie Kirk will be held Sunday afternoon in Glendale, Arizona. Doors open at 11 a.m. ET and the service begins at 2 p.m. ET.

The service was held at State Farm Stadium, with the same level of security as the Super Bowl. The stadium is home to the NFL’s Arizona Cardinals, with a capacity of 63,000 people to 73,000 people for larger events.

The nearby Desert Diamond Arena served as overflow space to accommodate an additional 19,000 people.

READ MORE: https://kutv.com/news/nation-world/service-and-funeral-for-charlie-kirk-starts-in-glendale-az#

snippet.title: Museum shares difficult history of Topaz living conditions
snippet.description:
Life was difficult for Japanese-American families who were working to adjust and rebuild their lives in central Utah.

The Topaz Internment Camp near Delta, Utah, cost just under $4 million to build.

According to historians, before being sent to Topaz during World War II, many people of Japanese descent were detained at the Tanforan and Santa Anita racetracks in California.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/belonging-in-utah/museum-shares-difficult-history-of-topaz-living-conditions

snippet.title: Teen stabbed in parking lot during Spanish Fork homecoming dance
snippet.description:
A 17-year-old male was stabbed in a Spanish Fork high school parking lot during the school's homecoming dance.

Police responded to Maple Mountain High School after receiving a report of a possible stabbing just after 9:20 p.m. Saturday, according to officials with the Spanish Fork Police Department.

Upon arrival, police said they found a 17-year-old male with a stab wound in his leg. Medical first responders treated the victim at the scene and transported him to a nearby hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.

snippet.title: Salem residents petition against planned 45-mile transmission project near homes, wetlands
snippet.description:
One neighborhood in Salem is fighting back after it received word from Utah County that Rocky Mountain Power wants to put up a 45-mile transmission line project nearby.

Salem Park is the only neighborhood that sits next to Rocky Mountain Power's proposed transmission line project that would run from substations in Spanish Fork to Eagle Mountain.

"We're not anti-power. We're not anti-grid. We're just anti-bad placement of things," said Joseph Ybarra, who lives in Salem Park.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/utahs-growing-pains/salem-residents-petition-against-planned-45-mile-transmission-project-near-homes-wetlands

snippet.title: Sheriff reveals new details on the arrest of Tyler Robinson
snippet.description:
Sheriff Nate Brooksby discussed Washington County's involvement in the arrest of Tyler Robinson.

Robinson, age 22, was charged on Tuesday with aggravated murder, felony discharge of a firearm, two counts of capital obstruction of justice, two counts of tampering with a witness, and a violent offense committed in the presence of a child in the killing of political activist Charlie Kirk.

Robinson was taken into custody on Sept. 11 — 33 hours after the deadly shooting.

Brooksby said he was winding down for the evening when, at approximately 8:02 p.m., he received a call from his friend, a retired detective.

According to Brooksby, his friend shakily said something along the lines of, "Hey, I know who Charlie Kirk's shooter is. I know the family through religious association, and he's in Washington County now."

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/local/washington-co-sheriff-details-how-tip-from-retired-detective-brought-in-tyler-robinson-charlie-kirk-utah-valley-university-orem-st-george-spanish-fork-assassination

snippet.title: Protester interrupts RFK Jr. opening statement defending 'MAHA' health agenda
snippet.description:
Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. defended his "Make America Healthy Again" agenda during a heated congressional hearing on Thursday against members of both parties.

Kennedy testified before the Senate Finance Committee, where he faced tough questions amid the ouster of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention director and big changes in vaccine policy.

Susan Monarez was ousted as CDC director after less than a month on the job.

Kennedy, a noted vaccine skeptic, remade the expert advisory panel that develops vaccine recommendations for the CDC.

Isaias Emanuel Carranza, 16, is accused of shooting and killing Mason Caballero, also 16, near the high school earlier this week.

Carranza is accused of three counts of aggravated murder, a first-degree felony; 25 counts of felony discharge of a firearm, a second-degree felony; and one count of possession of a dangerous weapon by a minor, a third-degree felony.

snippet.title: The Food Nanny's Beef Stroganoff
snippet.description:
Discover more at: https://TheFoodNanny.com

I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this meal!! And it’s so easy and great to serve company. My daughter-in-law Kim made this dish for us once with filet mignon, and it was a real treat! My daughter has a son who requests this meal once a week. She makes this recipe and then divides it into single serving portion sizes. She puts the individual meals into freezer containers and keeps them handy for when her son NEEDS to have his Beef Stroganoff. I think this is a great idea for a single person or couple that will have plenty of leftovers. It comes out tasting just as good as the day you made it. xo

snippet.title: Rebecca Lafferty writes a new book about growing up as the daughter of the infamous Dan Lafferty
snippet.description:
Rebecca Lafferty has a well-known last name, all due to her father Dan Lafferty. Dan is serving two life sentences for the murder of his sister-in-law and her infant daughter.

Rebecca's new book, The Lafferty Girl: Surviving Trauma, Abuse, and My Father's Crimes, describes her growing up in a strict religious household and one that was controlling, abusive, and featured a lot of trauma.

She joined ARC Salt Lake to discuss her book and her relationship, then and now, with her father, Dan.

snippet.title: Debris cleanup shuts down stretch of Bonneville Shoreline Trail in Provo
snippet.description:
To remove debris from consecutive mudslides triggered by the Buckley Draw Fire burn scar, Provo City closed a one-mile section of the Bonneville Shoreline Trail.

On Aug. 27 and again on Sept. 22, the city of Provo said two big rain events brought mud and debris down the Buckley Draw burn scar into this diversion channel.

The first of the two mudslides sent thousands of pounds of mud into a church on South Slate Canyon Drive.

snippet.title: Former Springville officer Kati Powell cleared of wrongdoing by Utah certification agency
snippet.description:
A former officer with the Springville Police Department, who was fired for dishonesty and unethical conduct, was cleared of wrongdoing by the state agency responsible for certifying police officers in Utah.

Police Chief Lance Haight terminated Kati Powell after responding to a home where she suspected children were being emotionally abused.

However, the Peace Officer Standards and Training agency found insufficient evidence of a violation of the Utah Code that allows POST to suspend or revoke peace officer certification. The council has the authority to issue a Letter of Caution, or suspend or revoke the certification of a peace officer, and lists several things, including this, which applied to Powell since the police department terminated her employment:

snippet.title: FULL INTERVIEW: Dirt biker explains running into wire trap in American Fork Canyon
snippet.description:
Daniel Bender of Alpine, Utah, was riding his dirt bike on his favorite trail — Hidden Forest Trail — when he was suddenly knocked off by a trap.

"Somebody put a wire, like a black wire, between two trees and strung it across the trail right about neck height," he said. "It could have been a lot worse." 

The Utah County Sheriff's Office opened an investigation, according to public information officer Sgt. Ray Ormond.

"There's hikers, mountain bikers, horseback riders, and of course dirt bikes, and it's one of my favorite places to ride," Bender said. “Somebody put a wire, like a black wire, between two trees and strung it across the trail right about neck height."

He said that he and his friend took photos and removed the wire, and later filed a police report with the Utah County Sheriff's Office.

snippet.title: Utah Co. Attorney reads texts between murder suspect and partner before Charlie Kirk killing
snippet.description:
The Utah County Attorney’s Office filed charges against Tyler Robinson, the man accused of shooting and killing political activist Charlie Kirk.

Robinson, age 22, was charged on Tuesday with aggravated murder, a first-degree felony; felony discharge of a firearm, a first-degree felony; two counts of capital obstruction of justice, a second-degree felony; two counts of tampering with a witness, a third-degree felony; and violent offense committed in the presence of a child, a class A misdemeanor.

Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was shot at Utah Valley University on Wednesday.

snippet.title: Landslide forces road closure in Bluffdale expected to last several hours
snippet.description:
A landslide in Bluffdale forced road closures, which police said are expected to last overnight.

Officials with the Jordan Valley Water Conservancy District said they were conducting regular maintenance and pumping water into a canal when the water began flowing onto 14600 South near Spring View Parkway.

They said the ground was oversaturated and could not hold the water, causing debris to flow. City and state officials confirmed that the culvert did not overflow and there was no waterline break.

snippet.title: Violinist speaks about ICE detainment after returning to Utah
snippet.description:
A Utah violinist detained by ICE a few weeks ago shared the details of his detainment after being released from custody.

John Shin shared his experience publicly on Friday, saying his detention was "a very shocking moment" for him. Shin was detained on Aug. 18 while on a work trip in Colorado.

“I never thought I would know what it feels like to be shackled by my ankles and my wrists. Feeling like some sort of serious criminal. As if I had murdered someone,” said John Shin, a Utah violinist who was released from ICE custody.

snippet.title: Take 2 Podcast: Politics, fallout of Charlie Kirk’s assassination
snippet.description:
Hosted by Heidi Hatch with guests Maura Carabello of the Exoro Group and Utah GOP Chair Rob Axson

On this week’s Take 2 Podcast, we look at the assassination of conservative commentator Charlie Kirk on the campus of Utah Valley University in Orem. Utah GOP Chair Rob Axson, a friend of Kirk, and Maura Carabello of the Exoro Group join the discussion on the political and emotional fallout one week later.

Topics this week:
Charlie Kirk assassination at UVU

George Zinn, known in political circles, diverted police attention and was arrested on child pornography charges
22-year-old Tyler Robinson, the accused shooter, faces the death penalty
Utah released Robinson’s mugshot despite state law prohibiting it
A Pennsylvania man was arrested in Utah after posting an online threat against UVU
Debate over university security and whether DPS or local law enforcement should step in
Businesses and universities firing employees over online comments after the assassination
Utah’s special session pushed back to Oct. 6

Utah Legislature releases list of lawmakers who will oversee redistricting

Two weeks until Congress faces its budget deadline

READ MORE: https://kutv.com/news/take-2/take-2-podcast-politics-fallout-of-charlie-kirks-assassination

snippet.title: Former Gov. Gary Herbert talks about impact of government shutdown on Utah families
snippet.description:
Utah faced a week of major events shaping both state and national conversations — from the federal government shutdown to the death of President Russell M. Nelson, leader of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and the special session on redistricting.

To help make sense of it all, KUTV spoke with former Gov. Gary Herbert — who led the state from 2009 to 2021 and guided the Beehive State through multiple national challenges, including a previous federal shutdown.

Herbert shared his perspective on how the current shutdown is hitting local families, the economic ripple effects on jobs and national parks, and how state leaders are responding. He also reflected on President Nelson’s legacy and offered insight into what’s at stake as lawmakers return to the Capitol for redistricting.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/arc-salt-lake/former-gov-gary-herbert-talks-about-impact-of-government-shutdown-on-utah-families

snippet.title: Why firefighters are more prone to lung cancer
snippet.description:
Nearly one in five people develops cancer in their lifetime, and for firefighters lung cancer is a big risk in their line of work.

Joining ARC Salt Lake is Michael Conn who is with the Firefighter Cancer Support Network and a firefighter. His wife Amy Conn is a cancer survivor and has a new book coming out about living through cancer.

snippet.title: Photos released of person of interest in Charlie Kirk assassination
snippet.description:
OREM, Utah (KUTV) — The FBI has released two photos of a new person of interest in connection to the fatal shooting of Charlie Kirk at Utah Valley University.

The FBI offered a reward of up to $100,000 for information leading to the identification and arrest of the individual responsible for Kirk's murder.

Anyone in the public who may have information identifying the person to call investigators at 1-800-CALL-FBI or leave a tip at www.fbi.gov/utahvalleyshooting.

Kirk, a political activist, was shot and killed while attending a planned event on the UVU campus where he engaged in open debates with attendees.

snippet.title: 'You have made Charlie Kirk immortal': Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller
snippet.description:
Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller vowed to keep political activist Charlie Kirk's fight alive at Kirk's memorial. 

The public memorial service and funeral for political activist Charlie Kirk will be held Sunday afternoon in Glendale, Arizona. Doors open at 11 a.m. ET and the service begins at 2 p.m. ET.

The service was held at State Farm Stadium, with the same level of security as the Super Bowl. The stadium is home to the NFL’s Arizona Cardinals, with a capacity of 63,000 people to 73,000 people for larger events.

The nearby Desert Diamond Arena served as overflow space to accommodate an additional 19,000 people.

snippet.title: Arizona police prepare top level security for Charlie Kirk memorial under tight deadline
snippet.description:
The Glendale Police Department in Arizona has years of experience hosting high-security events, but time constraints and the presence of prominent politicians made preparing for Charlie Kirk's memorial more challenging.

On Wednesday, Sept. 10, political activist Charlie Kirk was shot and killed at Utah Valley University in Utah during his American Comeback Tour.

Now, just over a week after his assassination, all eyes are shifting to the State Farm Stadium in Glendale, Arizona, where a massive security presence will surround his memorial on Sunday.

snippet.title: FULL INTERVIEW: Nationwide CDL freeze leaves thousands of immigrant truckers without work
snippet.description:
A new emergency action plan by the U.S. Secretary of Transportation has temporarily paused the issuance and renewal of commercial driver's licenses across the country.

States must now audit their licensing systems, which have left many legal non-citizens unsure if they can keep working.

“I got to keep driving down these roads of a country that doesn't really want me here,” said Jorge Rivera, a truck driver from Enoch, Utah.

snippet.title: State Representative Karen Peterson shares memories of Sgt. Jared Jensen
snippet.description:
State Representative Karen Peterson, House Rules Vice Chair from District 13, shared her memories of Jensen moving from the Sunset Police Department to the Clinton Police Department

“We expertly acquired him from the Sunset Police Department to come work for our police department in Clinton, that was a nice way of saying we poached him, and it was a good move on our part,” she said.

She highlighted his dedication and impact on public safety. She recalled his narrow escape cheating death after he was ambushed in 2012, which fueled his advocacy for victims and led to legislative changes. That incident is something he talked extensively about with 2News Investigates in 2021.

snippet.title: Gov. Cox urges Utahns to 'log off' after graphic Charlie Kirk shooting video spreads
snippet.description:
After laying out evidence in the investigation into the deadly shooting of political activist Charlie Kirk, Utah Gov. Spencer Cox shifted his remarks Thursday to the disturbing video that has been widely shared online.

“We are not wired as human beings biologically, historically, we have not evolved in a way that we are capable of processing those types of violent imagery,” Cox said. “This is not good for us. It is not good to consume.”

The governor drew a parallel to another dark time in U.S. history, comparing the moment Kirk was shot in front of thousands to political violence in the 1960s when JFK and MLK were shot and killed.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/local/gov-cox-urges-utahns-to-log-off-after-graphic-charlie-kirk-shooting-video-spreads

snippet.title: Utah prosecutors plan to seek death penalty against suspect in Charlie Kirk assassination
snippet.description:
The Utah County Attorney’s Office filed charges against Tyler Robinson, the man accused of shooting and killing political activist Charlie Kirk.

Robinson, age 22, was charged on Tuesday with aggravated murder, a first-degree felony; felony discharge of a firearm, a first-degree felony; two counts of capital obstruction of justice, a second-degree felony; two counts of tampering with a witness, a third-degree felony; and violent offense committed in the presence of a child, a class A misdemeanor.

Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was shot at Utah Valley University on Wednesday.

snippet.title: How does Utah honor Sept. 11?
snippet.description:
Former Utah governor Gary Herbert joined ARC Salt Lake to discuss a variety of topics.

He gave good tips on how to honor what happened 24 hours ago on 9/11 and how he found out about the terrorist attack in New York City.

He also discusses his thoughts on the latest in Utah's redistricting process that is going through the courts, and how local and state law enforcement should interact with federal enforcement.

snippet.title: Smithfield council member threatens to defund police department in heated body cam footage
snippet.description:
VIDEO COURTESY The Logan Herald Journal City Councilor Outburst

A local city council member is facing backlash after a heated exchange with police officers, which was all captured on body camera footage. The incident, which occurred on August 3, 2025, has raised serious questions about the council member’s conduct and his stance on the local police department.

Smithfield City Council member Ted Stokes is under scrutiny after a tense confrontation with police officers at his home. The officers had responded to a complaint regarding a car crash involving Stokes’ son. While the crash resulted in only minor injuries—a bloody nose—Stokes did not take kindly to the police response.

Body camera footage obtained by The Herald Journal shows Stokes threatening to shrink the city’s police force, suggesting that only five officers should remain on the department. He also mocked the officers and criticized their training.

“I promise you I will do everything in my power as a city council member to make sure these guys are defunded,” Stokes is heard saying in the video. “There will be five police officers in this town because this is unbelievable.”

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/local/smithfield-council-member-threatens-to-defund-police-department-in-heated-body-cam-footage

She also gives a measles update and how vaccines are the best protection of the highly contagious disease.

snippet.title: Pete Hegseth's call to live worthy of Charlie Kirk's sacrifice
snippet.description:
Secretary of War Pete Hegseth said that political activist Charlie Kirk was a fighter despite never having gone to West Point at Kirk's memorial. 

The public memorial service and funeral for political activist Charlie Kirk will be held Sunday afternoon in Glendale, Arizona. Doors open at 11 a.m. ET and the service begins at 2 p.m. ET.

The service was held at State Farm Stadium, with the same level of security as the Super Bowl. The stadium is home to the NFL’s Arizona Cardinals, with a capacity of 63,000 people to 73,000 people for larger events.

The nearby Desert Diamond Arena served as overflow space to accommodate an additional 19,000 people.

snippet.title: Utah Gov. Cox says he wants to pursue death penalty for Charlie Kirk murder suspect during presser
snippet.description:
Utah Gov. Cox announced his plans to pursue the death penalty in the assassination of political activist Charlie Kirk.

In a press conference Thursday evening, Utah Department of Public Safety Commissioner Beau Mason went through surveillance footage and still images of the person of interest.

The footage showed the suspect on a Utah Valley University roof. After the shots were fired, the suspect moved to the far right corner, climbed to the edge, and jumped off the building.

As he did that, he left palm impressions and a shoe imprint.

snippet.title: Tyler Robinson to virtually attend hearing with attorney as defense team takes shape
snippet.description:
Tyler Robinson, the man accused of fatally shooting Charlie Kirk on Utah Valley University's campus, is expected back in court, this time with his appointed attorney.

He was scheduled to appear in court in person for the first time on Monday, but officials with the Utah County Attorney's Office announced Saturday that he would be appearing virtually instead.

2News spoke with criminal defense attorney Skye Lazaro—who is not affiliated with this case—about what to expect from this highly publicized case.

She said Monday's hearing should be simple and quick, but the timeline for the case as a whole will likely be anything but.

snippet.title: Trump reveals commitment of $1 trillion dollars to 2026 military funding
snippet.description:
President Donald Trump declared on Tuesday that the military will not be politically correct when it comes to defending American freedom after Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth vowed that the Department of War is "done with that sh**," in reference to what he called "toxic ideological garbage."

The leaders addressed hundreds of top U.S. military officials after they were summoned last Thursday to the Marine Corps base in Quantico by the Pentagon.

“This administration has done a great deal from day one to remove the social justice, politically correct, and toxic ideological garbage that had infected our department, to rip out the politics, no more identity months, DEI offices, dudes in dresses. No more climate change worship, no more division, distraction, or gender delusions. No more debris," Hegseth told the room full of the military's senior officers.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/nation-world/president-donald-trump-and-defense-secretary-pete-hegseth-set-to-speak-with-hundreds-of-military-leaders-in-mystery-meeting-marine-corps-base-quantico-government-shutdown-warrior-ethos#

snippet.title: Utah officers, students face emotional and physical toll after Charlie Kirk assassination
snippet.description:
There have been multiple high-profile shootings in Utah over the past few weeks, raising concerns about the emotional and physical toll these cases have on law enforcement and community members.

The Charlie Kirk shooting came on the heels of another significant act of violence, where two Tremonton-Garland police officers were shot and killed.

snippet.title: Road debris causes hundreds of crashes on Utah roads
snippet.description:
SALT LAKE CITY (KUTV) — Road debris has caused hundreds of crashes on Utah roads.

Just in September, one person died after hitting debris on I-15, and a teenage girl was impaled by rebar.

snippet.title: Beware of free, fake wi-fi: Cybersecurity expert says AI empowers such scams
snippet.description:
The federal government says scams of all kinds are on the rise and advances in artificial intelligence are making the problem worse.

One scam that is easier to perpetuate with the help of AI is the so-called "evil twin" scam in which attackers create a fake wireless network that mimics a legitimate one.

Victims fall for the trap when they are in public places that offer free wi-fi - like airports, shopping centers or coffee shops.

snippet.title: Woman carries cultural ritual of coffee readings from Istanbul to Utah
snippet.description:
A centuries-old tradition that transcends borders is brewing in Salt Lake City — one that’s less about caffeine and more about connection.

Coffee readings, also known as tasseography, is an ancient practice across the Mediterranean, Middle East, and Balkans that has long served as a way to spark conversation and reflection. And for Isil Hessick, who goes by Ishelle, it’s a cultural ritual she carried with her from Istanbul to Utah 24 years ago.

“We have a saying that if you share a cup of Turkish coffee, you’re committed to a 40-year friendship,” she said.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/eye-on-utah/woman-carries-cultural-ritual-of-coffee-readings-from-istanbul-to-utah

snippet.title: SPECIAL COVERAGE: 22-year-old Tyler Robinson booked on aggravated murder for death of Charlie Kirk
snippet.description:
OREM, Utah (KUTV) — The suspected gunman in the assassination of Charlie Kirk was arrested and booked into the Utah County Jail.

During a press conference Friday morning, Gov. Spencer Cox identified the suspect as Tyler Robinson, a 22-year-old man from Washington City, Utah.

Court documents show Robinson was booked into the Utah County Jail on charges of first-degree felony aggravated murder, first-degree felony discharge of a firearm, and second-degree felony obstruction of justice. Gov. Cox previously indicated the state would be pursuing the death penalty for the suspected gunman.

snippet.title: Lehi residents claim new bike lanes create confusion, parking issues
snippet.description:
New bike paths in Lehi were added last year to improve the road's safety, but nearby residents said the design has caused a host of issues.

Bike lanes were added on 700 South and 500 West in Lehi in July 2024 with the purpose of improving safety for bikers and cutting down on speeding on that stretch. 700 South is a two-lane road, with the bike path running in two directions on one side of the road, and streetside parking next to it in the middle of the road.

Residents said they felt they weren't consulted about this change when the bike lanes were put in, and have concerns with the design.

snippet.title: Independent review launched into Charlie Kirk assassination to improve campus safety
snippet.description:
An independent organization will conduct a review of Charlie Kirk's assassination at Utah Valley University in an effort to strengthen campus safety measures.

UVU officials announced the independent review into the assassination on Monday, adding that it will be conducted by an external organization. They said the review is intended to improve campus preparedness and response to safety threats.

“We believe the findings of the comprehensive, third-party independent review of this targeted act of violence will offer valuable insights on how college campuses improve response and preparedness moving forward,” said UVU President Astrid S. Tuminez.

snippet.title: Family, church leaders honor life, legacy of Pres. Russell M. Nelson in funeral service
snippet.description:
A capacity crowd of roughly 21,000 mourners filled The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints Conference Center at Temple Square to honor the life and legacy of President Russell M. Nelson.

Services started at noon and were presided by President Dallin H. Oaks. Among Tabernacle Choir performances, members of Nelson's family, including his daughter Gloria N. Irion and son Russell M. Nelson Jr., shared memories about their childhood and growing up with Nelson.

Church leaders including Relief Society General President Camille N. Johnson, Elder Jeffrey R. Holland, Elder Henry B. Eyring and President Oaks also spoke at Nelson's funeral.

snippet.title: Great Salt Lake project could double US lithium production
snippet.description:
A remote stretch of northern Utah, where cattle graze on expansive ranches and elk roam in the wild, could become the place where U.S. production of a crucial mineral is super-charged — a mineral used for batteries in cell phones, computers, and electric vehicles.

Lilac Solutions, an Oakland-based firm, announced this week the "successful completion of lithium pilot operations” near the lake shore in Box Elder County.

Now, it plans a “commercial facility” that “would double current U.S. lithium production” in a “non-contaminating process(that) does not lower lake levels.”

snippet.title: U of U law professor 'hopeful but cautious' about Israel/Hamas ceasefire deal
snippet.description:
A University of Utah law professor who lives in Israel for half the year remains cautiously optimistic as the prospect of a potential peace deal between Israel and Hamas looms.

“I’m the only child of two Holocaust survivors,” Amos Guiora said. “And that’s critical to understanding this. I, by nature, am an optimist; otherwise, you can’t be the only child of two Holocaust survivors.”

Guiora has been to multiple demonstrations, marches, and walks at Hostage Square in Tel Aviv, calling for an end to the war and for the release of the hostages by Hamas.

snippet.title: FULL VIDEO: Sheriff reveals new details on the arrest of Tyler Robinson
snippet.description:
Sheriff Nate Brooksby discussed Washington County's involvement in the arrest of Tyler Robinson.

Robinson, age 22, was charged on Tuesday with aggravated murder, felony discharge of a firearm, two counts of capital obstruction of justice, two counts of tampering with a witness, and a violent offense committed in the presence of a child in the killing of political activist Charlie Kirk.

Robinson was taken into custody on Sept. 11 — 33 hours after the deadly shooting.

Brooksby said he was winding down for the evening when, at approximately 8:02 p.m., he received a call from his friend, a retired detective.

According to Brooksby, his friend shakily said something along the lines of, "Hey, I know who Charlie Kirk's shooter is. I know the family through religious association, and he's in Washington County now."

snippet.title: #BREAKING: Charlie Kirk dies after shooting at Utah Valley University rally
snippet.description:
BREAKING UPDATE: Charlie Kirk has died after being shot at a Utah Valley University rally on Wednesday, Sept. 10. He was 31. 

President Donald Trump confirmed his death on Truth Social.

"The Great, and even Legendary, Charlie Kirk, is dead. No one understood or had the Heart of the Youth in the United States of America better than Charlie," he posted. "He was loved and admired by ALL, especially me, and now, he is no longer with us. Melania and my Sympathies go out to his beautiful wife Erika, and family. Charlie, we love you!"

He was shot at 12:10 p.m. in the quad near the food court. He was allegedly discussing shooting and gang violence at the time.

"We are confirming that he was shot and we are praying for Charlie," said Aubrey Laitsch, public relations manager for Turning Point USA.

snippet.description:
Tens of thousands filled State Farm Stadium on Sunday to honor Charlie Kirk, just over a week after the conservative activist was shot and killed on the campus of Utah Valley University.

For five hours on Sunday, friends, Turning Point USA staff and cabinet members shared memories before Vice President JD Vance, President Donald Trump and Kirk’s widow, Erika, took the stage.

Charlie Kirk's widow, Erika Kirk, gave an emotional speech, speaking of her last moments with her husband's body and her forgiveness of his killer.

snippet.title: Suspected gunman booked on aggravated murder for death of Charlie Kirk
snippet.description:
The suspected gunman in the assassination of Charlie Kirk was arrested and booked into the Utah County Jail.

During a press conference Friday morning, Gov. Spencer Cox identified the suspect as Tyler Robinson, a 22-year-old man from Washington City, Utah.

Court documents show Robinson was booked into the Utah County Jail on charges of first-degree felony aggravated murder, first-degree felony discharge of a firearm, and second-degree felony obstruction of justice. Gov. Cox previously indicated the state would be pursuing the death penalty for the suspected gunman.

Lawmakers failed to pass a funding measure before the fiscal year deadline. As a result, the federal government officially shut down shortly after midnight on Wednesday.

snippet.title: FanX bans AI-generated art to protect original artists
snippet.description:
Artificial intelligence has crept into nearly every aspect of modern life — including art. But at this year’s FanX Salt Lake Comic Convention, AI-generated art won’t be welcome.

When the event opens on Sept. 25, only artists selling original work will be allowed to display and sell at the convention. The decision is meant to protect creators and ensure fans know what they are buying.

FanX founder and producer Dan Farr said that while AI art has not yet posed a problem at the Salt Lake convention, concerns about misrepresentation at other events led to the ban.

snippet.title: Traffic, tourism expected to spike as St. George Marathon attracts thousands
snippet.description:
Nearly 9,000 runners are expected to race through southern Utah as the 49th St. George Marathon kicks off Saturday morning.

The 26.2-mile trek starts in Central, winds through red rocks along SR-18, and ends in St. George, where runners will cross the finish line at Vernon Worthen Park.

As visitors arrive for the race, the town expects traffic to increase. There will be several road closures across Washington County starting Friday night, with most closing Saturday at 3 a.m.

snippet.description:

Daniel Workman was arrested on Wednesday after investigators executed a search warrant on his home and discovered child sex abuse materials on accounts belonging to him.

The Utah Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force and the St. George Police Department led the investigation.

snippet.title: Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins highlighted role of farmers, ranchers in MAHA initiative
snippet.description:
U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who chairs the commission, emphasized the administration's commitment to tackling the issue.

"The Trump Administration is mobilizing every part of government to confront the childhood chronic disease epidemic," Kennedy said. "This strategy represents the most sweeping reform agenda in modern history—realigning our food and health systems, driving education, and unleashing science to protect America’s children and families."
U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Brooke L. Rollins highlighted the role of farmers and ranchers in the initiative.

"America’s farmers and ranchers are at the heart of the solution—alongside doctors, parents, and communities—to fight chronic disease and protect future generations," Rollins said.
She noted efforts such as securing commitments to remove artificial food dyes from major brands and providing technical assistance to states interested in restricting junk food and soda from SNAP.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/nation-world/rfks-make-america-healthy-again-commission-unveils-strategy-to-combat-childhood-diseases#

snippet.title: Latter-day Saints church fully engulfed in flames after shooting that injures multiple people
snippet.description:
GRAND BLANC, Mich. (AP) — A gunman opened fire inside a Mormon church in Michigan during Sunday services before apparently setting the building ablaze, killing at least one person and injuring nine before police shot him, authorities said

Hundreds of people were inside The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Grand Blanc Township when a 40-year-old man rammed a pickup truck through the front door, then got out of the vehicle and started shooting, Police Chief William Renye told reporters. Police believe he “deliberately” set the building on fire.

After the suspect left the church, two officers pursued him and “engaged in gunfire,” Renye said. The man was killed.

FULL STORY: https://bit.ly/42hFlNY

snippet.title: UDOT begins major Provo bridge reconstruction
snippet.description:

The Utah Department of Transportation is replacing the Highway 189 bridge near 920 South and 400 South in Provo. The project will cost around $70 million and is expected to be completed in Fall 2027.

“I work down here, so I drive up probably almost every day,” said Danny Sellers, who worries his daily commute will be affected. “I think that it's going to be interesting."

snippet.title: Family, friends of Esperanza Chavez got justice they were seeking for her murder
snippet.description:
A man the Salt Lake County District Attorney’s Office gave repeated plea deals to in domestic violence cases pleaded guilty to murder.

Fred Jason Edwards, 48, a convicted felon with a violent criminal record dating back decades, tried to gouge a guards eyes out while he was an inmate at the Salt Lake County Metro jail; attacked his girlfriend, causing her to jump from a moving car; and texted his mother that if she called his probation officer he would chop her in half — ending the text message with a disparaging and offensive term for a sexually promiscuous woman.

All of this precipitated the murder of Esperanza Chavez, who started dating Edwards in 2023.

snippet.title: Cherry Fire expands to 650 acres in Hobble Creek Canyon, east of Springville
snippet.description:
The Cherry Fire has burned more than 650 acres east of Springville and Mapleton in Hobble Creek Canyon.

Officials stated that the blaze remained active throughout the night and into Friday morning. They anticipated increased activity due to predicted weather conditions, such as high winds, ahead of the weekend storm.

The fire remains 0% contained, but according to Utah Fire Info, fire managers feel confident that crews will achieve some containment along the southern edge of the fire near South Fork Hobble Road.

Turning Point USA returns to Utah for a panel discussion featuring Sen. Mike Lee and Gov. Spencer Cox at Utah State University.

snippet.title: Heavy Rains Worsen Road Conditions Throughout Utah
snippet.description: Heavy rains worsen road conditions throughout Utah as storms enter the state. And motorcycle crashes are down in the Beehive State but fatalities have increased, prompting concerns from the Department of Public Safety.

snippet.title: Former Box Elder County judge asks court for bail on child sex charges
snippet.description:
A former northern Utah judge has asked to be released more than six months after he was arrested for child sex crimes.

Kevin Christensen, who held a black-robed position of trust for decades, was brought to an Ogden courtroom, shackled and in a jail jumpsuit.

Christensen's lawyer, Ryan Bushell, said the defense has not been provided pertinent case information requested weeks ago and asserted, in a court filing, that Christensen would comply with court-ordered conditions for his release pending trial.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/local/former-box-elder-county-judge-asks-court-for-bail-on-child-sex-charges

snippet.title: "In Charlie's name": Stephen Miller next move
snippet.description:
Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller vowed to keep political activist Charlie Kirk's fight alive at Kirk's memorial. 

The public memorial service and funeral for political activist Charlie Kirk will be held Sunday afternoon in Glendale, Arizona. Doors open at 11 a.m. ET and the service begins at 2 p.m. ET.

The service was held at State Farm Stadium, with the same level of security as the Super Bowl. The stadium is home to the NFL’s Arizona Cardinals, with a capacity of 63,000 people to 73,000 people for larger events.

The nearby Desert Diamond Arena served as overflow space to accommodate an additional 19,000 people.

snippet.title: Festa Italiana has something for everyone
snippet.description:
This weekend is the Festa Italiana, and it is a fun event for a good cause.

Joining ARC Salt Lake was a varity of groups to discuss what the vent has. There was pizza, Vespas, and a Ferrari to see.

This event helps a lot of local charities over the years, including Catholic Community Services, The Italian Club of Salt Lake, Prevent Child Abuse Utah, The Inn Between, and The Sammy Center.

snippet.title: How will the government shutdown impact your finances?
snippet.description:
With the United States government shutdown, there is a lot of uncertainty, especially with finances.

There could be issues with medical costs and food benefits that are received from the federal government.

Plus, everyday things we expect to go on as normal, might now face delays. Those things can include things ranging from visits to national parks to heading to the airport to take a flight.

snippet.description:
The suspected gunman in the assassination of Charlie Kirk was arrested and booked into the Utah County Jail.

Tyler James Robinson, 22, was arrested on suspicion of aggravated murder, a first-degree felony; discharge of a firearm, a first-degree felony; and capital obstruction of justice, a second-degree felony.

snippet.title: Canyons School District proposes boundary changes, school closures as enrollment drops
snippet.description:
The Canyons School District may see some elementary schools close, and students across several campuses may be reassigned under new recommendations released this week.

Years of declining enrollment at the elementary level forced the district to consider consolidations, boundary changes, and school closures. Four proposals are now on the table, each with varying impacts on families.

“It’s hard, but we also know the district is in a hard place,” said Jenny Basford, whose child attends Granite Elementary.

snippet.title: Utah's Attorney General is protecting kids from online exploitation
snippet.description:
One of Utah Attorney General Derek Brown's goals is to protect kids in Utah. He, along with the FTC, is making sure that kids are not being exploited online.

Pornographic companies have been fined and are forced to monitor what goes online and remove content that is illegal. Brown wants to hold those companies accountable to make sure their content is not hurting kids.

He wants people to get along better, even if they disagree, and put a stop to this type of political violence.

snippet.description:

The event was held about three weeks after Charlie Kirk's assassination at Utah Valley University, roughly 120 miles south of USU.

"I think it's pretty calm today," USU student McKell Carter said on Wednesday.

snippet.title: Family release identity of Ogden teen killed in shooting near Ben Lomond High School
snippet.description:
The family of the 16-year-old boy shot and killed near Ben Lomond High School released his identity on Wednesday.

The boy was identified as Mason Caballero through a GoFundMe posted to support the Caballero family and cover the costs of the funeral and memorial services.

Caballero was fatally shot on October 7 near the Ben Lomond High School campus. Capt. Tim Scott with the Ogden Police Department said Caballero went to the Ben Lomond High School campus seeking help, and a school safety officer and other school staff attempted life-saving measures. Caballero, however, died due to his injuries.

snippet.title: Washington County struggles to keep up with increase in homelessness
snippet.description:
Homelessness is on the rise across Utah, with both veterans and elderly people seeing the steepest increase in 2025. In Washington County, where there are just 124 year-round emergency shelter beds, it has become difficult to keep up with the growing demand.

"Homelessness starts in a million different ways," said Zachary Almaguer, Director of Communications at Switchpoint. "But there are things that are no secrets to any of us — rising prices, jobs looking shaky, and general economic uncertainty."

Switchpoint is a nonprofit shelter and community resource provider that began in St. George and has since expanded statewide. It operates more than a dozen facilities from Washington County to Salt Lake and Davis counties, offering both emergency and longer-term housing solutions.

snippet.title: "We got him": Gov. Cox on arrest of Charlie Kirk assassination suspect
snippet.description:
Utah Gov. Spencer Cox later confirmed Robinson's identity.

Bullet casings found near the rifle were engraved several messages, according to Gov. Cox. Inscriptions included "Notices Bulges OWO What's this?" on a fired casing. On three unfired casings, inscriptions included "Hey Facist! Catch!" with one up arrow, a right arrow and three down arrows, "Oh Bella Ciao, Bella Ciao, Bella Ciao Ciao Ciao" and a third casing read "If you read this, you are gay, lmao."

A manhunt for the suspect started just after noon on Sept. 10 when Kirk, a political activist known for touring university campuses and debating students, was shot and killed.

Kirk was making an appearance in the Utah Valley University's quad in Orem for the first stop of his "American Comeback Tour." He was discussing gun violence and mass shooting with a student when he was fatally shot.

Early in the investigation, state and federal officials said they tracked the shooters movements from the time he got onto UVU's campus around 11:52 a.m. - about 20 minutes before the single gunshot. Video footage captured the suspect running from the shooting location across a nearby roof.

Investigators recovered what they believe to the murder weapon, a high-powered bolt action rifle, which was sent to an FBI laboratory for analysis. Investigators also collected a palm imprint, a shoe imprint, and forearm imprints from the scene.

snippet.title: Utah prosecutors plan to seek death penalty against suspect in Charlie Kirk assassination
snippet.description:
The Utah County Attorney’s Office filed charges against Tyler Robinson, the man accused of shooting and killing political activist Charlie Kirk.

Robinson, age 22, was charged on Tuesday with aggravated murder, a first-degree felony; felony discharge of a firearm, a first-degree felony; two counts of capital obstruction of justice, a second-degree felony; two counts of tampering with a witness, a third-degree felony; and violent offense committed in the presence of a child, a class A misdemeanor.

Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was shot at Utah Valley University on Wednesday.

snippet.title: Enbridge asks judge to partially dismiss lawsuit in deadly South Jordan gas explosion
snippet.description:
Attorneys for Enbridge Gas appeared in court, asking a judge to dismiss part of the wrongful death lawsuit filed by the family of a South Jordan teenager killed in a gas explosion nearly a year ago.

The hearing in Salt Lake County’s 3rd District Court centered on a motion from Enbridge to dismiss the strict liability claim in the case involving 14-year-old Logan Hansen, who died when his family’s home exploded last November.

Justin Toth, an attorney representing Enbridge, told the court the company’s request was not meant to minimize the family’s loss.

snippet.title: LATEST: New person of interest in Charlie Kirk assassination; Vice President JD Vance in Utah
snippet.description:
The FBI has released two photos of a new person of interest in connection to the fatal shooting of Charlie Kirk at Utah Valley University.

The FBI offered a reward of up to $100,000 for information leading to the identification and arrest of the individual responsible for Kirk's murder.

Anyone in the public who may have information identifying the person to call investigators at 1-800-CALL-FBI or leave a tip at www.fbi.gov/utahvalleyshooting.

Kirk, a political activist, was shot and killed while attending a planned event on the UVU campus where he engaged in open debates with attendees.

Vice President JD Vance will visit Utah to pay respects to Charlie Kirk and his family, according to multiple reports.

Lt. Col. Christopher Kroeber of the Utah National Guard confirmed Vance would be landing at the Air National Guard Base for a private meeting with Kirk's family.

Vance and Second Lady Usha Vance were scheduled to travel to New York City to visit Ground Zero on the anniversary of the 9/11 terror attacks. However, according to reports from the Associated Press, Vance canceled their plans and planned a visit with Kirk's family in Salt Lake City.

MORE: https://kutv.com/news/local/fbi-releases-photos-of-person-of-interested-connected-to-charlie-kirk-killing

snippet.title: Utah Valley University hosts 'Vigil for Unity' in wake of Charlie Kirk assassination
snippet.description:
Utah Valley University is hosting a vigil in the wake of last week's tragic shooting.

Charlie Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was fatally shot during an event on campus on Wednesday, Sept. 10.

According to UVU Emergency Information, the vigil aims to provide a space for students, faculty, staff, and community members to come together in remembrance and healing.

snippet.title: Donald Trump Jr.: 'We will not be afraid' when speaking about Charlie Kirk's assassination
snippet.description:
Donald Trump Jr. recalled speaking events he attended with Charlie Kirk where their lives were threatened, but Kirk would not back down. 

Trump Jr. was one of many who spoke at Kirk's memorial service at the State Farm Stadium in Arizona. 

The service was held at State Farm Stadium, with the same level of security as the Super Bowl. The stadium is home to the NFL’s Arizona Cardinals, with a capacity of 63,000 people to 73,000 people for larger events.

The nearby Desert Diamond Arena served as overflow space to accommodate an additional 19,000 people.

snippet.description:

Robinson, age 22, was charged on Tuesday with aggravated murder, felony discharge of a firearm, two counts of capital obstruction of justice, two counts of tampering with a witness, and a violent offense committed in the presence of a child in the killing of political activist Charlie Kirk.

Robinson was taken into custody on Sept. 11 — 33 hours after the deadly shooting.

Brooksby said he was winding down for the evening when, at approximately 8:02 p.m., he received a call from his friend, a retired detective.

snippet.title: Witness claims lack of security near Charlie Kirk at Utah Valley University event
snippet.description:
OREM, Utah (KUTV) — A Utah man said he stood just feet away from Charlie Kirk when the political activist was shot.

Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was fatally shot at Utah Valley University on Wednesday.

"I was only maybe 15 feet, not even 15 feet away from him," Skyler Baird said. "And I heard the pop, and I said in my mind, 'That was a gunshot.'"

snippet.title: Nearly four months since 15-year-old Kylie Arellano seen in Northeastern Utah
snippet.description:
Where is Kylie Arellano? The question still lingers with family, friends and law enforcement who've been trying to locate the 15-year-old who left her home on May 29, 2025 in Garden City, Utah.

Kylie, whose been featured on 'Utah's Missing' since her disappearance, missed the start of 10th grade and will turn 16-years-old in October. Her mother hasn't given up hope and continues to ask to anyone who thinks they've seen someone who looks like Kylie; to take a photo or video and share it with law enforcement immediately.

“I put flyers up everywhere I could; I’ve done what I can," said Kylie's mother Stephanie Coleman to 2News on Wednesday, September 24. "When I say she vanished off the face of this earth, I mean that.”

There's been no contact from Kylie with family or friends and no social media activity for roughly 117 days. Her mother believes she was coerced into leaving her home; although she's confirmed with Kylie's friends that she also discussed 'running away'. 

2News spoke with the Rich County Sheriff's Office on Wednesday. The Deputy who took over the case confirmed they've had possible sightings or tips and have followed up on each lead. 

According to Kylie's mother, there is no surveillance video showing Kylie in the Garden City area from the day(s) surrounding her disappearance. Kylie's 'missing' status is listed on two national databases including National Missing and Unidentified Persons System (NamUs) and National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC). It's not clear why Kylie is not listed on the Utah Department of Public Safety's missing person database. 

Kylie is 5'6" and weighs 115 lbs. She has chin-length brown hair and brown eyes. She has black braces and tattoos.

If you have any information, contact the Rich County Sheriff's Office: 435-793-2285, referencing case #25-R308.

snippet.title: TIMELINE: Prosecutors build capital murder case against Tyler Robinson in Charlie Kirk shooting
snippet.description:
Prosecutors and defense attorneys have begun outlining their next moves in the high-profile case of Tyler Robinson, the man accused of assassinating Charlie Kirk at Utah Valley University.

On September 10th, 2025, 31-year-old political activist Charlie Kirk was assassinated in broad daylight on the campus of Utah Valley University. One bullet. 3,000 witnesses. And a 33-hour manhunt.

Charlie Kirk brought his "Prove Me Wrong" tour to Utah Valley University. At 12:23 PM, just 23 minutes into the event, a student asked him about mass shootings in America. As Charlie began to answer, a single gunshot rang out from 200 yards away. The bullet struck him in the neck.

The shooter? Gone. Vanished into a nearby neighborhood.

For 33 hours, the FBI and Utah authorities searched. They recovered a high-powered rifle in the woods. They found footprints, palm prints, surveillance footage. They offered a $100,000 reward. But the shooter had disappeared.

FULL STORY: https://bit.ly/4pPfxmj

snippet.title: Charlie Kirk shot at Utah Valley University event
snippet.description:
Charlie Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was shot at Utah Valley University.

As of 1:50 p.m., Kirk was in critical condition, being treated.

He was shot at 12:10 p.m. in the quad near the food court. He was allegedly discussing shooting and gang violence at the time.

“We are confirming that he was shot and we are praying for Charlie,” said Aubrey Laitsch, public relations manager for Turning Point USA.

The suspect was taken into custody.

snippet.title: Salt Lakers push back against proposed 15-acre homeless campus
snippet.description:
Salt Lakers are pushing back against a proposed 15-acre homeless service campus.

The facility, to be located at 2520 N. 2200 West, would include 1,300 beds and offer wraparound services such as addiction recovery, criminal justice assistance, employment help, and housing support.

It's part of the state’s effort to address a growing homelessness crisis. Last year, Utah saw an 18% increase in homelessness.

snippet.title: Missing since October 1964: Where is Reed Jeppson?
snippet.description:
The disappearance of 15-year-old Reed Taylor Jeppson from October 11, 1964 is believed to be one of Utah's oldest cold cases.

Jeppson left his home after returning from church with his family. He left to feed his two dogs and take them for a walk. Reed and the two dogs were never found. Various searches were conducted for Reed, and it's unclear if any of his clothing was ever located.

"We call these 'cold cases' but we don't ever consider these 'cold cases'," said Sgt. Miles Southworth with Salt Lake City Police Department. "This one, for instance, we continue working it. I was browsing through the case today, and we have over 150 reports between now and 1964. There have been a lot of people that have looked at this case, continued revisiting it, continued following leads."

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/utahs-missing/missing-since-october-1964-where-is-reed-jeppson

snippet.title: Family of missing mother Tina Jones conducts search; disappeared in 2023
snippet.description:
CLEARFIELD, Utah — The family of a woman who disappeared more than two years ago recently conducted a search in Davis County.

The family of Tina Maria Jones, 52, reported her missing on Aug. 28, 2023. They said they last had contact with her on Aug. 9, and she checked out of a homeless shelter in Salt Lake City on Aug. 13.

Between Aug. 13 and Aug. 16, Jones was reportedly staying with an acquaintance at Clearfield Junction Apartments, located at 101 North Main Street. Residents there told police that they last saw Jones on Aug. 16 and said she left behind all of her personal belongings — aside from her wallet — at the apartment. Surveillance cameras from a nearby building show a woman resembling Jones walking on a sidewalk heading west towards the Center Street Bridge.

"We want to find her, we just want to find her," said Madison Madrigal, Tina's daughter in a recent interview with 2News. "We just want closure, you know?"

Family and friends of Tina Jones helped with a search on September 13, 2025.

Jones was described as being 5'5" and approximately 180 lbs with dark brown hair in a pixie cut. She was last seen wearing a dark-colored shirt and dark-colored pants. Jones is considered endangered due to her mental illness.

Anyone who has seen or had contact with Jones around the time of or after Aug. 16, 2023 is asked to call Clearfield Police Dispatch at (801) 525-2806.

snippet.title: Ogden City leaders plan to build surf wave in middle of Weber River
snippet.description:
The City of Ogden wants to build a surf wave in the middle of the Weber River, roughly a quarter-mile downstream from the current Kayak Park that was rebuilt in 2021.

In that stretch of river, there is what is called a "concrete weir" that the city has identified as a navigation hazard.

The project seeks to replace the weir with the surf wave, which would cost about $3 million.

snippet.title: Suspect appears at initial hearing after formal charges filed in Charlie Kirk murder case
snippet.description:
The Utah County Attorney’s Office filed charges against Tyler Robinson, the man accused of shooting and killing political activist Charlie Kirk.

Robinson, age 22, was charged on Tuesday with aggravated murder, a first-degree felony; felony discharge of a firearm, a first-degree felony; two counts of capital obstruction of justice, a second-degree felony; two counts of tampering with a witness, a third-degree felony; and violent offense committed in the presence of a child, a class A misdemeanor.

Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was shot at Utah Valley University on Wednesday.

Robinson appeared for his initial court appearance Tuesday afternoon before a judge. 

MORE: https://kutv.com/news/local/utah-county-attorney-announces-formal-charges-against-man-in-charlie-kirk-assassination

snippet.title: BREAKING: Political activist Charlie Kirk shot at Utah rally Wednesday
snippet.description:
Charlie Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was shot at Utah Valley University.

As of 1:50 p.m., Kirk was in critical condition, being treated.

He was shot at 12:10 p.m. in the quad near the food court. He was allegedly discussing shooting and gang violence at the time.

“We are confirming that he was shot and we are praying for Charlie,” said Aubrey Laitsch, public relations manager for Turning Point USA.

The suspect was taken into custody.

snippet.title: Engravings on bullet casings offer clues into motive in Charlie Kirk assassination
snippet.description:
Tyler James Robinson, a 22-year-old accused of assassinating Charlie Kirk, is under intense scrutiny as investigators delve into potential motives behind the killing.

Despite having no prior criminal record, Robinson's actions are being examined through the lens of anti-fascist messages found on bullet casings.

Greg Rogers, a retired FBI agent with 30 years of experience, said, “I think that he believed that Charlie Kirk, in his mind, he would have described Charlie Kirk as fascist.”

snippet.title: Parents urged to limit kids' screen time, monitor devices as Kirk videos spread online
snippet.description:
As news continues to come out surrounding the investigation of the assassination of Charlie Kirk, some parents say they’re concerned about the videos their kids are watching online. Is there anything parents can do to filter out the videos they don’t want their kids to see?

Even if you specifically put a phrase like “KUTV Charlie Kirk,” and you click on one of those videos, you’re going to be pointed to a slew of other posts about him, both positive and negative. Some parents we’ve spoken with say they don’t want their kids watching Charlie Kirk’s speeches, while others tell us they don’t want their kids seeing videos of people celebrating his death.

Tech insiders say there is very little parents can do to sift out the videos they don’t want their kids watching.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/local/parents-urged-to-limit-kids-screen-time-monitor-devices-as-kirk-videos-spread-online

snippet.title: Utah Legislature honors Sgt. Jared Jensen's legacy, service posthumously with citation
snippet.description:
The Utah Legislature honored the life and contributions of Kaysville Police Sergeant Jared Jensen, who passed away on June 9 after valiantly battling brain cancer.

Before the special session began, the Utah Senate and Utah House of Representatives presented a citation to his family expressing formal condolences of the legislative body to his wife Camille and their two children Greyson and Oakley, his parents Gary and Michelle Jensen, and many other family members in recognition of his legacy.

snippet.title: Washington Co. sheriff details how Tyler Robinson was brought in
snippet.description:
Sheriff Nate Brooksby discussed Washington County's involvement in the arrest of Tyler Robinson.

Robinson, age 22, was charged on Tuesday with aggravated murder, felony discharge of a firearm, two counts of capital obstruction of justice, two counts of tampering with a witness, and a violent offense committed in the presence of a child in the killing of political activist Charlie Kirk.

Robinson was taken into custody on Sept. 11 — 33 hours after the deadly shooting.

Brooksby said he was winding down for the evening when, at approximately 8:02 p.m., he received a call from his friend, a retired detective.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/local/washington-co-sheriff-details-how-tip-from-retired-detective-brought-in-tyler-robinson-charlie-kirk-utah-valley-university-orem-st-george-spanish-fork-assassination

snippet.title: 'We have a man here who was tremendously loved by his community'
snippet.description:
Sgt. Jared Jensen’s family went over to the Utah Senate, where Senator Jerry Stevenson told Senate President Stuart Adams that they had special visitors from the Kaysville Police Department and Jensen’s family, who had all suffered a “tremendous loss.”

Sen. Stevenson said, “We have a man here who was tremendously loved by his community, and that would be the law enforcement central-northern Davis County community.”

Sen. Stevenson said it was his honor to recognize Sgt. Jensen, “And the remarkable public servant that he was for the courage, the character, and the lasting impact he left on law enforcement in his community and in surrounding communities. Sgt. Jensen’s career reflected the very best of public safety, dedication, humility, and unwavering sense of duty.”

snippet.title: Utah prosecutors plan to seek death penalty against suspect in Charlie Kirk assassination
snippet.description:
PROVO, Utah (KUTV) — The Utah County Attorney’s Office officially filed charges against Tyler Robinson.

Robinson, age 22, was charged on Tuesday with aggravated murder, a first-degree felony; felony discharge of a firearm, a first-degree felony; two counts of capital obstruction of justice, a second-degree felony; two counts of tampering with a witness, a third-degree felony; and violent offense committed in the presence of a child, a class A misdemeanor.

He is scheduled to make his first court appearance in Fourth District Court in Provo virtually, from the Utah County Jail in Spanish Fork.

While Utah Attorney General Derek Brown has not announced if authorities would pursue the death penalty, President Donald Trump and Utah Gov. Spencer Cox have been vocal about their support for it.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/local/utah-county-attorney-announces-formal-charges-against-man-in-charlie-kirk-assassination

snippet.title: "Guided by wisdom and courage": Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Charlie Kirk's life
snippet.description:
The public memorial service and funeral for political activist Charlie Kirk will be held Sunday afternoon in Glendale, Arizona. Doors open at 11 a.m. ET and the service begins at 2 p.m. ET.

The service will be held at State Farm Stadium, with the same level of security as the Super Bowl. The stadium is home to the NFL’s Arizona Cardinals, with a capacity of 63,000 people to 73,000 people for larger events.

The nearby Desert Diamond Arena served as overflow space to accommodate an additional 19,000 people.

Glendale, where the stadium is located, is home to Kirk’s organization, Turning Point USA.

snippet.title: Court switches to virtual hearing for Charlie Kirk's suspected killer
snippet.description:
Tyler Robinson, the man accused of killing Charlie Kirk at Utah Valley University, will now be appearing in court virtually for a waiver hearing after a recent change in plans.

Robinson was expected to appear in Utah County Court on Monday at 10 a.m. in person for the first time since his arrest.

However, officials with the Utah County Attorney's Office announced Saturday that he will be appearing virtually from the Utah County Jail instead.

Officials with the attorney’s office said changing an in-person hearing to a virtual one could be due to security concerns, or the defense counsel may have concerns about the perception of their client showing up in shackles.

snippet.title: Utah DPS commissioner gives update on search for Charlie Kirk's killer
snippet.description:
Utah Department of Public Safety Commissioner Beau Mason gave an update early Thursday morning on the search for Charlie Kirk's killer.

The suspect remains at large but Commissioner Mason said he was confident in the department's abilities and will move forward in a manner that keeps everyone safe.

"The heinous event that happened yesterday is not Utah. This is not what we're known for," said Mason.

"Over the past several weeks, we've seen the state come together to help families in mourning. Come together as a community to show what Utah is known for. For a state of character, of service, of comradery, of a neighboring-feel."

snippet.description: STREAMING: FBI director, Utah governor give update on investigation into assassination of Charlie Kirk.

snippet.title: Utah Valley University holds campus 'Vigil for Unity' after Charlie Kirk's assassination
snippet.description:
Utah Valley University is hosting a vigil in the wake of last week's tragic shooting.

Charlie Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was fatally shot during an event on campus on Wednesday, Sept. 10.

According to UVU Emergency Information, the vigil aims to provide a space for students, faculty, staff, and community members to come together in remembrance and healing.

MORE: https://bit.ly/4msO0Ex

snippet.title: Utah Dept. of Public Safety speaks on Charlie Kirk fatal shooting; No suspect in custody
snippet.description:
Charlie Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was fatally shot at Utah Valley University Wednesday.

FBI Director Kash Patel originally said that a person of interest was taken into custody before 4:20 p.m., but was released by 6 p.m.

"Our investigation continues," he said.

snippet.title: STREAMING: Traffic backed up after crash forces three lanes closed near Jeremy Ranch in Summit Co.
snippet.description:
Two people were injured in a multi-vehicle crash.

The crash happened on westbound I-80 near Jeremy Ranch, where two lanes were already closed for construction.

Lt. Cameron Roden with Utah Highway Patrol said a box truck merged to the left and hit a Subaru.

The Subaru bounced off and came back to the right, hitting another semi-truck in the fuel tank.

About 100-150 gallons of fuel spilled.

snippet.title: Utah leaders focus on growth, opportunity in rural communities at statewide summit
snippet.description:
Efforts to boost opportunity and manage growth in rural Utah dominated discussions during a summit where state leaders examined challenges in jobs, education, water, and housing.

“You can’t govern from Capitol Hill,” said Lt. Gov. Deirdre Henderson at the One Utah Summit for rural leaders at Southern Utah University. The key conversation: concerns and solutions for rural communities, including jobs, education, water, and affordable housing.

Henderson said growth is both a challenge and an opportunity.

snippet.title: St. George loses $87 million in funding meant to connect both sides of downtown, divided by I-15
snippet.description:
St. George has lost $87 million in federal funding for a project meant to connect the east and west sides of the city with new underpasses. 
 
The cuts come from the Trump Administration's “Big Beautiful Bill,” which rescinded certain Biden-era grants
 
The Utah Department of Transportation was originally awarded the funding. City leaders said the project would reduce congestion, improve safety and connect both sides of downtown – becoming even more crucial as St. George continues to expand.

snippet.title: Former wrestling coach remembers heroic man killed by suspected drunk driver
snippet.description:
A Utah community is mourning the loss of the man struck and killed by an alleged drunk driver while out walking with his wife.

Loved ones called Matthew Daines, 25, a hero after he reportedly pushed her out of the way — sacrificing his life to save hers.

“He was a Superman always,” said his longtime wrestling coach, Craig Miner. “Great man. They don’t come better.”

snippet.title: Take 2: Israel-Hamas peace deal moves forward, day 9 of government shutdown
snippet.description:
Take 2 Podcast – October 9, 2025

Hosts: Heidi Hatch

Guests: Maura Carabello, Exoro Group; Trent Staggs, Riverton Mayor and Small Business Administrator
_____
ISRAEL–HAMAS PEACE DEAL MOVES FORWARD

President Donald Trump announced that Israel and Hamas have agreed on the first phase of a peace framework that would allow for the swift release of all hostages.

Still missing from the plan are key details on Hamas’s disarmament and who will govern Gaza once the deal moves ahead. Those issues are expected to be part of later negotiations.
_____
GOVERNMENT SHUTDOWN – DAY 9

The federal government shutdown has entered its ninth day, with Affordable Care Act subsidies still a sticking point for Democrats.

Republicans have centered their messaging around health care for migrants, pushing for limits on taxpayer-funded benefits.

In Utah, undocumented migrants can access emergency medical care, and some coverage is available for children.
_____
NEW NUMBERS – UTAH RANKS 3RD IN MIGRANT ARRIVALS

Salt Lake City is now one of the nation’s fastest-growing destinations for migrants, according to new data from U.S. Customs and Border Protection.

Between May 2023 and January 2025, nearly 2.5 million migrants who entered the U.S. — either illegally or through legal protection under the CBP One app — reported where they planned to live.

Miami led with 2,191 arrivals per 100,000 residents, followed by Fort Myers, Florida, at 1,782. Salt Lake City ranked third with 1,685, just ahead of Denver and New York.

AP Source
_____
NEW ICE DIRECTOR – AGREEMENTS WITH UTAH CITIES AND COUNTIES

The new ICE director is expanding partnerships with Utah law enforcement under three models:

Task Force Model – Local officers working directly with federal agents.
Jail Enforcement Model – ICE cooperation within county jails.
Warrant Service Officer Model – Deputized officers allowed to serve immigration-related warrants.
_____
UTAH SPECIAL SESSION

Lawmakers passed and the governor signed Map C, the new congressional redistricting plan. The map now heads to a judge for approval.

With the new boundaries, Utah could see as many as two competitive races in the 2026 election cycle.

snippet.title: Utah families face uncertainty as WIC funds dwindle due to government shutdown
snippet.description:
A federal food program for Utah women and children has a week or two left before its contingency funding runs dry due to the ongoing government shutdown.

According to officials with Utah WIC, the federal food and nutrition program for women, infants, and children, they have about two weeks of contingency funding on hand as of Oct. 1, unless the federal government shutdown ends.

snippet.title: FULL INTERVIEW: Attorney breaks down Tyler Robinson death penalty case in Charlie Kirk killing
snippet.description:
A death penalty case against Tyler Robinson, the accused assassin of Charlie Kirk, is beginning to take shape.  Prosecutors face a mountain of video evidence, eyewitness accounts, and questions about how to prove others were put at risk, the aggravating factor that makes this a death penalty case. 

Here is Jim Spiewak’s full interview with attorney Nathan Evershed, who is not affiliated with the case breaking down the strategies both sides may use as this high-profile case moves forward.

snippet.title: Suspect in Charlie Kirk assassination placed in special jail unit, awaiting formal charges
snippet.description:
The man accused of assassinating Charlie Kirk at UVU was temporarily placed in the Utah County Jail's special housing unit and is expected to be formally charged next week. But there are still a lot of unknowns when it comes to the prosecution of this case.

Tyler Robinson, 22, was booked in the Utah County Jail on aggravated murder, discharge of a firearm, and obstruction of justice charges.

Officials with the Utah County Sheriff's Office said he was placed in the special housing unit until he could be cleared by medical staff and moved to the "appropriate housing for the charges." They said the unit has around-the-clock physical supervision.

snippet.title: Mourners reflect on life, legacy of Latter-day Saint leader President Nelson
snippet.description:
Tributes are pouring in from around the world after the passing of President Russell M. Nelson, leader of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, who died just weeks after celebrating his 101st birthday.

Dan Farr, producer of FanX Salt Lake Comic Convention, shared a personal connection with the Church president.

“He saved my life,” Farr said. “When I was five years old in 1973, Russell Nelson operated on my heart. It’s very personal for me.”

Farr shared that even decades later, President Nelson remembered the exact details of the surgery.

“He actually mentioned the date and told me details about the surgery—it was amazing, the mind that he had,” he said.
