snippet.title: 13-year-old struck, killed while riding e-bike in Farmington
snippet.description:
A 13-year-old boy was struck and killed while riding an e-bike in Farmington.

Officials with the Farmington Police Department said officers responded to reports of a crash near 1525 West and 600 South shortly after 4:30 p.m. on Friday. They said it was reported that a teenager was hit and was injured and not breathing.

Upon arrival, officers found multiple people attempting to provide medical aid and CPR to the victim. Medical first responders arrived and continued aiding the victim. The 13-year-old boy was then transported to the hospital by ambulance, where he was later pronounced dead.

snippet.title: Dozens unknowingly exposed to dangerous levels of radiation for months at St. George lab
snippet.description:
More than two dozen people said they were unknowingly exposed to dangerous levels of radiation for months after a CT lab in St. George was built without a lead wall that was supposed to protect them.

The lawsuit, filed this week in Fifth District Court, alleges Intermountain Healthcare hired Medical Physics Consultants to design shielding plans for a new CT lab. Those plans called for a lead-lined drywall to keep radiation out of neighboring offices.

Intermountain Health hired CRC Construction to execute the plans. CRC Constructed subcontracted B & S Drywall.

snippet.title: Salt Lakers push back against proposed 15-acre homeless campus
snippet.description:
SALT LAKE CITY (KUTV) — Salt Lakers are pushing back against a proposed 15-acre homeless service campus.

The facility, to be located at 2520 N. 2200 West, would include 1,300 beds and offer wraparound services such as addiction recovery, criminal justice assistance, employment help, and housing support.

It's part of the state’s effort to address a growing homelessness crisis. Last year, Utah saw an 18% increase in homelessness.

snippet.title: No new temples announced at general conference after President Nelson's passing
snippet.description:
President Oaks did not announce any new temples at The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints' seminannual general conference in October.

Oaks, the leader of the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles for The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, spoke at the end of the two-day conference, taking the place of the late Church president.

He started his talk speaking on temple announcements, a practice that had become somewhat of a tradition under President Russell M. Nelson's leadership.

He said President Nelson had announced 200 temples during his time as president, adding that now is an "appropriate" time to slow down announcements as construction on the temples continues.

snippet.title: Dems clash with RFK JR.on CDC, vaccines

snippet.title: Fans left wondering if they'll get refunds after weather forces REDWEST evacuations
snippet.description:
Many were left wondering if they'll get refunds for the REDWEST Country Music Festival after Saturday's show was canceled due to severe weather.

Thousands of fans packed into the Utah State Fairpark this weekend for the festival. Saturday's severe weather forced fans to take cover and eventually evacuate.

The night's headliner — Post Malone — never made it to the stage.

snippet.title: Developers propose master-planned community for rural Weber County
snippet.description:
A major development could be coming to the fields and farmlands of western Weber County, as developers have proposed a large master-planned community in the area.

“I like that it’s rural,” said longtime resident Jared Warner. “You’ve got the open fields, you can have animals... hunt down the road. A little more space and freedom.”

But that could change as developers proposed a master-planned community with more than 13,000 homes and 38,000 residents, stretching over 1,400 acres near 12th Street and the Union Pacific railroad tracks.

snippet.title: Former dance teacher loses use of her legs after being hit by semi-truck on the freeway
snippet.description:
A former dance teacher lost the use of her legs in a crash.

Michele Bayock pulled over to the side of the freeway after traffic stopped suddenly on an interchange nearly two weeks ago. She was hit from behind by a semi-truck.

She survived, but she has a long road ahead. She has a serious spinal cord injury along with damage to her ribs and lungs, on top of the loss of feeling in her legs.

snippet.title: Timeline traces Charlie Kirk’s final moments after Utah shooting, search for suspect
snippet.description:
UPDATE: Suspect arrested in murder of Charlie Kirk.

FULL STORY: https://bit.ly/3HTiDow

***************

Political activist Charlie Kirk was shot and killed on the campus of Utah Valley University. Kirk was on campus for his American Comeback Tour, a debate-style event called “Prove Me Wrong.” 

Just minutes into the program, as Kirk was answering a student question a gunman who authorities believe was positioned on the roof of the Losee Center fired a single round. 

The bullet struck Kirk in the neck. 

Cell phone video shows the chaotic aftermath as blood poured from his wound and security rushed him to a waiting SUV.

snippet.title: UDOT begins major Provo bridge reconstruction
snippet.description:
PROVO, Utah (KUTV) — Utah County drivers should prepare for delays and detours as a major reconstruction project begins.

The Utah Department of Transportation is replacing the Highway 189 bridge near 920 South and 400 South in Provo. The project will cost around $70 million and is expected to be completed in Fall 2027.

“I work down here, so I drive up probably almost every day,” said Danny Sellers, who worries his daily commute will be affected. “I think that it's going to be interesting."

snippet.title: FULL STATEMENT: Utah Gov. Cox says "we got him" on Charlie Kirk murder suspect
snippet.description:
The suspected gunman in the assassination of Charlie Kirk was arrested and booked into the Utah County Jail.

President Donald Trump first reported 'with a high degree of certainty' that suspect in Charlie Kirk killing has been caught.

During an appearance on Fox & Friends early Friday, the president said the suspect was in custody, saying everybody did a "great job."

"We worked with the local police, the governor, everybody did a great job," Trump said.

The President said somebody "very close" to the suspect turned him in but deferred to state and federal officials to provide more information.

Utah Gov. Spencer Cox later confirmed Robinson's identity.

Bullet casings found near the rifle were engraved several messages, according to Gov. Cox. Inscriptions included "Notices Bulges OWO What's this?" on a fired casing. On three unfired casings, inscriptions included "Hey Facist! Catch!" with one up arrow, a right arrow and three down arrows, "Oh Bella Ciao, Bella Ciao, Bella Ciao Ciao Ciao" and a third casing read "If you read this, you are gay, lmao."

MORE: https://kutv.com/news/nation-world/trump-says-with-a-high-degree-of-certainty-suspect-in-charlie-kirk-killing-caught

The ninth-grade student from Canyon View Junior High School was killed during a school field trip on Wednesday. The student brought a loaded firearm and died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound in front of classmates and staff.

Gray Walker, a seventh grader at the school, said he learned about the shooting after his cross-country practice was canceled.

"We always do an after-action review with our internal teams, and then we also include our community partners to make sure that we've hit all the key points that we could, and also that we're ready for the future," said Brittany Lopez, Tooele County assistant manager.

snippet.title: Utah museum preserves history of World War II Topaz Internment Camp
snippet.description:
What started off as a high school classroom assignment for students in central Utah turned into a multi-million-dollar project honoring Japanese Americans who survived Topaz Internment Camp.

The town of Delta, located in central Utah, has a unique history indirectly tied to it. About 16 miles outside of town, visitors will find a massive stretch of desert space, where the United States government once ran the "Central Utah Relocation Center." It was later renamed the Topaz Internment Camp, commonly known as Topaz.

Topaz was one of 10 internment camps formed in the U.S. during World War II.

snippet.title: New video shows suspect in Charlie Kirk murder jump from building, move across campus
snippet.description:
A video showed the suspect in the murder of political activist Charlie Kirk jump from a building and move across the Utah Valley University campus.

Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was fatally shot on the Orem campus on Wednesday.

The video was shown in a press conference, where FBI Director Kash Patel, FBI Deputy Director Dan Bongino, Special Agent in Charge Robert Bohls, Lt. Gov. Deidre M. Henderson, and Utah Department of Public Safety Commissioner Beau Mason were in attendance.

Mason went through surveillance footage and still images of the person of interest, which Gov. Cox called "an evil human being."

snippet.title: Johnson's presser on the ongoing government shutdown
snippet.description:
Republicans and Democrats remain at an impasse on Monday as the government shutdown enters its sixth day and the possibility of layoffs escalates.

President Donald Trump blamed Democrats on Sunday when asked about his threat to fire federal workers.

"I call them Democrat layoffs. They're Democrat layoffs. They're causing it. We're ready to go back, you know," Trump told reporters before boarding Marine One. "We have a record-setting economy. We have a record-setting country. Prices are way down. We're doing better than the country has ever done, and the Democrats hate seeing that. It's up to them. Anybody laid off, that's because of the Democrats."

snippet.title: Thousands wait outside State Farm Stadium in Arizona for Charlie Kirk memorial
snippet.description:
Thousands of people wait for hours outside State Farm Stadium in Glendale Arizona for the memorial service of Charlie Kirk, assassinated on a college campus in Utah. 

President Donald Trump and prominent members of his "Make America Great Again" movement will pay tribute Sunday to conservative activist Charlie Kirk, whose slaying has marked a signal moment in America's fraught political atmosphere.

The memorial service for Kirk, whom Trump credits with playing a pivotal role in his 2024 election victory, is expected to draw tens of thousands of mourners, including Vice President JD Vance, senior White House officials and young conservatives shaped by the 31-year-old firebrand.

snippet.title: UTAH'S MISSING: Search continues for Kaysville father of three reported missing
snippet.description:
KAYSVILLE, Utah (KUTV) — A Kaysville man has been missing since Sunday and hasn't been seen or heard from since.

Colin Mills, a husband and father of three, left his home in Kaysville on foot on Sunday, September 14. According to Colin's family, he left without his wallet or phone and was near the 900 block of Crestwood Road at roughly 4:30 p.m.

"Colin is an introvert; he's a homebody. He's the sweetest, kindest person you'd meet in your whole life. He would give you everything," Colin's sister Erica said. "He was starting to struggle with mental health, depression, he was getting help for it though, so we all thought he was on the turnaround."

snippet.title: Nationwide CDL freeze leaves thousands of immigrant truckers without work
snippet.description:
A new emergency action plan by the U.S. Secretary of Transportation has temporarily paused the issuance and renewal of commercial driver's licenses across the country.

States must now audit their licensing systems, which have left many legal non-citizens unsure if they can keep working.

“I got to keep driving down these roads of a country that doesn't really want me here,” said Jorge Rivera, a truck driver from Enoch.

snippet.title: FULL PRESSER: Political activist Charlie Kirk dies after shooting at Utah university event
snippet.description:
Charlie Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was fatally shot at Utah Valley University Wednesday.

President Donald Trump confirmed his death on Truth Social.

FBI Director Kash Patel confirmed the person of interest was taken into custody before 4:20 p.m.

"The Great, and even Legendary, Charlie Kirk, is dead. No one understood or had the Heart of the Youth in the United States of America better than Charlie," President Trump posted. "He was loved and admired by ALL, especially me, and now, he is no longer with us. Melania and my Sympathies go out to his beautiful wife Erika, and family. Charlie, we love you!"

Kirk was shot at 12:10 p.m. in the quad near the food court. He was allegedly discussing shooting and gang violence at the time.

snippet.title: 'done with that sh**:' Pete Hegseth vows to end politically correctness in military overhaul
snippet.description:
President Donald Trump declared on Tuesday that the military will not be politically correct when it comes to defending American freedom after Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth vowed that the Department of War is "done with that sh**," in reference to what he called "toxic ideological garbage."

The leaders addressed hundreds of top U.S. military officials after they were summoned last Thursday to the Marine Corps base in Quantico by the Pentagon.

“This administration has done a great deal from day one to remove the social justice, politically correct, and toxic ideological garbage that had infected our department, to rip out the politics, no more identity months, DEI offices, dudes in dresses. No more climate change worship, no more division, distraction, or gender delusions. No more debris," Hegseth told the room full of the military's senior officers.

snippet.title: City council considers limiting number of pets allowed in American Fork households
snippet.description:
American Fork city officials are considering limiting the number of pets one household can have within city limits.

At Tuesday night's city council meeting, the council plans to review and take action on a proposed ordinance that would allow no more than three dogs or three cats four months of age or older in any dwelling unit or commercial establishment at any time.

American Fork residents had mixed reactions to the proposal ahead of the meeting.

snippet.title: Utah State University heightens security in preparation for Turning Point USA tour stop
snippet.description:
Turning Point USA returned to Utah to continue the tour nearly three weeks after the organization's founder, Charlie Kirk, was shot and killed at Utah Valley University.

The tour continued on Sept. 30 at Utah State University in Logan, roughly 120 miles north of the campus where Kirk was assassinated. The northern Utah university was one of Kirk's originally scheduled stops on his "American Comeback Tour."

In place of Kirk, the event featured Alex Clark, host of the "Real Alex Clark" podcast. She was joined by a panel of speakers, including Utah political leaders Sen. Mike Lee and Gov. Spencer Cox. Former Utah Rep. Jason Chaffetz and current Arizona Rep. Andy Biggs were also featured on the panel.

snippet.title: Site of Charlie Kirk shooting leaves stark reminder for students on return to class
snippet.description:
Students at Utah Valley University returned to class, but for many, the physical setting of their education now carries the emotional weight of a tragedy that unfolded just steps away. The courtyard—once a place of gathering and calm—has become a stark reminder of violence that struck the heart of their campus.

“That spot right there is where he died.” The return to campus has been anything but normal for students like sophomore Geovanny Morales, who said the trauma is difficult to shake.

“It still feels weird to see because that spot right there is where he died,” Morales said. “One shot I still really can’t believe it.”

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/local/charlie-kirk-assassination-leaves-permanent-mark-on-utah-valley-university-courtyard

snippet.title: 'Charlie was Fearless': Tucker Carlson speaks at Kirk's memorial service in Arizona
snippet.description:
Former TV personality Tucker Carlson talked about assassinated political activist Charlie Kirk's faith and fight at Kirk's memorial service in Arizona. 

The public memorial service and funeral for political activist Charlie Kirk will be held Sunday afternoon in Glendale, Arizona. Doors open at 11 a.m. ET and the service begins at 2 p.m. ET.

The service was held at State Farm Stadium, with the same level of security as the Super Bowl. The stadium is home to the NFL’s Arizona Cardinals, with a capacity of 63,000 people to 73,000 people for larger events.

The nearby Desert Diamond Arena served as overflow space to accommodate an additional 19,000 people.

snippet.title: UVU releases return schedule for faculty, students after Charlie Kirk assassination
snippet.description:
Officials with Utah Valley University announced that faculty and students will return to class in phases after Charlie Kirk was assassinated on campus.

UVU officials said there will be a "phased return," with employees returning earlier to campus on Monday, Sept. 15, and students returning on Wednesday, Sept. 17. The phases are so that faculty and staff can prepare to help students when they start classes.

While classes do not begin until Wednesday, Student Services will be available to help starting Tuesday.

snippet.title: Salt Lake City records highest rain totals in more than 120 years
snippet.description:
A Salt Lake City neighborhood is dealing with rising floodwaters after record-setting rains overwhelmed local drainage systems.

Saturday was the wettest day in Salt Lake City since 1901, with rain totals reaching 2.43 inches over the course of 24 hours. The most rain recorded in Salt Lake City was on May 3, 1901, with a total of 2.64 inches.

Multiple homes reported basement flooding, and city officials are working to prevent further damage.

snippet.title: Smithfield council member resigns after heated exchange with police draws criticism
snippet.description:
A Smithfield council member announced his resignation after a video of him threatening to defund police drew criticism from officials and residents.

Body cam footage shows Ted Stokes in a heated exchange with officers on Aug. 3 after his son was involved in a car crash.

The crash resulted in only minor injuries, but Stokes' response to officers arriving at his home raised questions about the council member's conduct and support of local police.

“I promise you I will do everything in my power as a city council member to make sure these guys are defunded,” Stokes is heard saying in the video. “There will be five police officers in this town because this is unbelievable.”

snippet.title: Latter-day Saints anticipate smooth leadership transition after President Nelson's death
snippet.description:
Now that President Russell M. Nelson has been laid to rest, many in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints are looking forward to what the church might be like under the leadership of expected incoming president, Dallin H. Oaks.

According to tradition, President Oaks, the senior-most member of the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles, is next in line.

People attending the funeral on Tuesday said they expect that President Oaks' leadership will be an extension of President Nelson's.

snippet.title: Pete Hegseth on Charlie Kirk: "This is the Turning Point for the USA"
snippet.description:
Secretary of War Pete Hegseth said that political activist Charlie Kirk was a fighter despite never having gone to West Point at Kirk's memorial. 

The public memorial service and funeral for political activist Charlie Kirk will be held Sunday afternoon in Glendale, Arizona. Doors open at 11 a.m. ET and the service begins at 2 p.m. ET.

The service was held at State Farm Stadium, with the same level of security as the Super Bowl. The stadium is home to the NFL’s Arizona Cardinals, with a capacity of 63,000 people to 73,000 people for larger events.

The nearby Desert Diamond Arena served as overflow space to accommodate an additional 19,000 people.

snippet.title: St. George event seeks to break stigma, combat Utah's high suicide rate
snippet.description:
Families and advocates will gather at Confluence Park this weekend in St. George for the Out of the Darkness walk, an event aimed at raising awareness about suicide prevention and offering support for those impacted by suicide.

The event is part of a series of 10 walks across Utah organized by the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention.

Organizers said the walks bring together survivors of suicide loss, attempt survivors, and community members to promote seeking help and breaking the stigma around mental health.

snippet.title: Former dance teacher loses use of her legs after being hit by semi-truck on the freeway
snippet.description:
SPANISH FORK, Utah (KUTV) — A former dance teacher lost the use of her legs in a crash.

Michelle Boyack pulled over to the side of the freeway after traffic stopped suddenly on an interchange nearly two weeks ago. She was hit from behind by a semi-truck.

She survived, but she has a long road ahead. She has a serious spinal cord injury along with damage to her ribs and lungs, on top of the loss of feeling in her legs.

snippet.title: Salem residents petition against planned 45-mile transmission project near homes, wetlands
snippet.description:
SALEM, Utah (KUTV) — One neighborhood in Salem is fighting back after it received word from Utah County that Rocky Mountain Power wants to put up a 45-mile transmission line project nearby.

Salem Park is the only neighborhood that sits next to Rocky Mountain Power's proposed transmission line project that would run from substations in Spanish Fork to Eagle Mountain.

"We're not anti-power. We're not anti-grid. We're just anti-bad placement of things," said Joseph Ybarra, who lives in Salem Park.

snippet.title: Take 2 Podcast: Redistricting new maps, Great Salt Lake woes, Charlie Kirk memorial
snippet.description:
Take 2 Podcast

Thursday, Sept. 25, 2025
Guests: Heidi Hatch, Maura Carabello (Exoro Group), Sen. Daniel McCay

Redistricting New Maps

Public comment period runs for 10 days, through Oct. 5
Feedback can be submitted at redistricting.utah.gov
Special session scheduled for Oct. 6 to vote on the new map
Final maps will be submitted to the courts for approval
 

Great Salt Lake Water Woes

Gov. Spencer Cox launches GSL 2034, a public-private charter urging all Utahns to help restore the lake
Comes with a $200 million pledge, half already committed by Ducks Unlimited over 10 years
New philanthropic coalition Great Salt Lake Rising aims to raise an additional $100 million within a year, led by Josh Romney
Cox wants lake elevation back to 4,198 feet by the 2034 Winter Olympics (currently at 4,191 feet)
 

Charlie Kirk Monument at UVU

Petition supporting memorial: 20,000 signatures
Petition opposing memorial: 13,000 signatures
UVU announced creation of a Memorial Committee, co-chaired by Scott M. Smith (UVU Board of Trustees, Qualtrics co-founder) and Amanda Covington (Utah Board of Higher Education chair)
Committee will include students, political leaders, and other stakeholders
 

USU Turning Point Event – Tuesday, Sept. 30

Featured guests: Gov. Spencer Cox, Sen. Mike Lee, Former Rep. Jason Chaffetz
Some surprise at Cox’s participation after past criticism from Charlie Kirk in 2022
Still unclear if the format will be a panel or Q&A
 

Sutherland Institute Transition

Rick Larsen to step down as CEO on Jan. 1, 2026, and become president emeritus
 

One Week Out from Possible Government Shutdown

Federal government faces shutdown if Congress fails to pass spending bill by Oct. 1
Republicans and Democrats remain divided, particularly over extending enhanced ACA premium subsidies

snippet.title: FBI Director Kash Patel speaks on arrest of Charlie Kirk assassination suspect
snippet.description:
Watch the full statement from FBI Director Kash Patel at a press conference in Utah Friday morning. 

A manhunt for the suspect started just after noon on Sept. 10 when Kirk, a political activist known for touring university campuses and debating students, was shot and killed.

Kirk was making an appearance in the Utah Valley University's quad in Orem for the first stop of his "American Comeback Tour." He was discussing gun violence and mass shooting with a student when he was fatally shot.

Early in the investigation, state and federal officials said they tracked the shooters movements from the time he got onto UVU's campus around 11:52 a.m. - about 20 minutes before the single gunshot. Video footage captured the suspect running from the shooting location across a nearby roof.

Investigators recovered what they believe to the murder weapon, a high-powered bolt action rifle, which was sent to an FBI laboratory for analysis. Investigators also collected a palm imprint, a shoe imprint, and forearm imprints from the scene.

MORE: https://kutv.com/news/nation-world/trump-says-with-a-high-degree-of-certainty-suspect-in-charlie-kirk-killing-caught

snippet.title: At least four dead, eight injured in shooting at Latter-day Saint church in Michigan
snippet.description:
A gunman opened fire inside a Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints chapel in Michigan during a Sunday service and set the building ablaze, killing at least four people and injuring eight others. Police shot and killed the suspect, authorities said.

Hundreds of people were inside the church in Grand Blanc Township when a man rammed a four-door pickup with two American flags in the truck bed through the front door, then got out of the vehicle and started shooting, Police Chief William Renye told reporters. Investigators believe he “deliberately” set the building on fire, Renye said.

snippet.description:

There was a large show of support on Tuesday for Meggan Sundwall during her detention hearing in Fourth Judicial District Court in Provo. Sundwall appeared virtually due to an unknown problem carrying out the order to transport her.

snippet.title: Judge’s report accuses Wasatch County sheriff of blocking key steps in road rage shooting
snippet.description:
Wasatch County completed its investigation into Sheriff Jared Rigby and his department, accused of interfering with investigations.

Wasatch County hired retired Utah State District Court Judge Richard McKelvie to investigate accusations of favoritism and intimidation within the Wasatch County Sheriff’s Office by the administration.

McKelvie determined that Sheriff Rigby and Undersheriff Josh Probst interfered with cases despite "relative inexperience" and "lack of knowledge" in conducting criminal investigations.

snippet.title: Southern Utah prepares for possibility of water shortage
snippet.description:
After a dismal snowpack, sustained drought conditions, and a relatively weak monsoon season, southern Utah is preparing for the possibility of a water shortage.

A newly proposed conservation plan outlines what the county will require municipalities to do should reservoirs run low.

Washington County is experiencing its second driest year in over 130 years, according to the Washington County Water Conservancy District. 2025 was just .02 inches of rainfall above the driest year on record in 1956.

snippet.title: Trump ties Tylenol use during pregnancy to autism, announces autism action plan
snippet.description:
President Donald Trump announced Monday that taking the pain relief drug acetaminophen during pregnancy can lead to a higher risk of autism for babies prior to birth.

Trump said that Tylenol, also known as acetaminophen, taken during pregnancy, "can be associated with a very increased risk of autism." He described the announcement as "historic steps to confront the crisis of autism," which he called a "horrible, horrible crisis."

snippet.title: Interagency security under pressure to protect Charlie Kirk memorial attendees
snippet.description:
As preparations continue for Charlie Kirk’s funeral, it’s not just the scale of the event drawing attention, it’s the security behind it.

With a SEAR Level 1 designation, federal agencies are stepping in to assist.

Chris Bertram, a retired deputy chief of police, said while the Charlie Kirk funeral is a high-profile national event, the people planning it have a lot of experience.

“Some of the greatest leaders I’ve dealt with it’s amazing that they have the mindset to make sure everything gets covered,” said Bertram.

snippet.title: $87 million funding pulled from St. George I-15 underpass project by 'Big Beautiful Bill'
snippet.description:
After UDOT lost funding for an $87.6 million infrastructure project in St. George, city officials say they are still searching for replacement funds as the window to complete the project begins to close.

St. George was awarded the nearly $90 million through the Biden-era Reconnecting Communities and Neighborhoods (RCN) grant program in 2024.

With the passage of President Trumps "Big Beautiful Bill," RCN funds were rescinded and the underpass project lost its federal funding.

The money had been earmarked for two new underpasses beneath I-15 designed to alleviate east-west congestion, improve safety for students at nearby Dixie High and Dixie Middle schools, and reconnect both sides of downtown.

MORE: https://bit.ly/3I9Hmos

snippet.title: FULL COVERAGE: Political activist Charlie Kirk dies following shooting at Utah university rally
snippet.description:
Charlie Kirk, the CEO and co-founder of the conservative youth organization Turning Point USA, was fatally shot at Utah Valley University.

President Donald Trump confirmed his death on Truth Social.

"The Great, and even Legendary, Charlie Kirk, is dead. No one understood or had the Heart of the Youth in the United States of America better than Charlie," he posted. "He was loved and admired by ALL, especially me, and now, he is no longer with us. Melania and my Sympathies go out to his beautiful wife Erika, and family. Charlie, we love you!"

He was shot at 12:10 p.m. in the quad near the food court. He was allegedly discussing shooting and gang violence at the time.

"We are confirming that he was shot and we are praying for Charlie," said Aubrey Laitsch, public relations manager for Turning Point USA.

snippet.title: Church President Russell M. Nelson passes away at age 101
snippet.description:
SALT LAKE CITY (KUTV) — President Russell M. Nelson of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has passed away, just over two weeks after his 101st birthday.

The Church announced his passing late Saturday evening. They said he passed away just after 10 p.m. at his Salt Lake City home.

Russell M. Nelson was set apart on January 14, 2018, as the 17th president of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints — a moment he called “a sacred and humbling experience” as senior apostles laid their hands on his head to ordain him.

Although he was 93 at the time, President Nelson quickly became known for his pace and energy, bringing bold leadership and sweeping changes to the global faith.

snippet.title: Utah attorney reports ICE agents checking HR offices for worker authorization
snippet.description:
Gritty raids and criminal roundups may be among the most visible images of ICE.

Not seen nearly as much, if at all, are ICE “inspections” at Utah companies, which an immigration lawyer said, based on his practice, are growing.

"Any of them (firms) who have had this experience are nervous about it,” said Joshua Irvine, who recalled receiving calls one-or-two-times a year to counsel companies put on ICE notice. Now, “it feels almost monthly.”

snippet.title: UTAH'S MISSING: Family of missing mother Tina Jones conducts search; disappeared in 2023
snippet.description:
CLEARFIELD, Utah — The family of a woman who disappeared more than two years ago recently conducted a search in Davis County.

The family of Tina Maria Jones, 52, reported her missing on Aug. 28, 2023. They said they last had contact with her on Aug. 9, and she checked out of a homeless shelter in Salt Lake City on Aug. 13.

Between Aug. 13 and Aug. 16, Jones was reportedly staying with an acquaintance at Clearfield Junction Apartments, located at 101 North Main Street. 

esidents there told police that they last saw Jones on Aug. 16 and said she left behind all of her personal belongings — aside from her wallet — at the apartment. Surveillance cameras from a nearby building show a woman resembling Jones walking on a sidewalk heading west towards the Center Street Bridge.

snippet.title: 'We are all Charlie': Donald Trump Jr. honors Kirk at memorial
snippet.description:
Donald Trump Jr. recalled speaking events he attended with Charlie Kirk where their lives were threatened, but Kirk would not back down. 

Trump Jr. was one of many who spoke at Kirk's memorial service at the State Farm Stadium in Arizona. 

The service was held at State Farm Stadium, with the same level of security as the Super Bowl. The stadium is home to the NFL’s Arizona Cardinals, with a capacity of 63,000 people to 73,000 people for larger events.

The nearby Desert Diamond Arena served as overflow space to accommodate an additional 19,000 people.

snippet.title: Hurricane High student center faces unexpected demand as teen homelessness rises
snippet.description:
Two months after building a resource center for teens, Hurricane High School needs help to keep up with its demand.

“No one anticipated the amount of food that we were going to go through,” said Brian Gunnell, an At-Risk coordinator.

The center, which opened in August, acts as a resource to youth experiencing homelessness and food insecurity. Organizers said its success has been unanticipated, with an average of 300 students utilizing the space a day.

snippet.title: Utah County prepares for latest aggravated murder case as resources stretched thin
snippet.description:
The Utah County court system is facing increasing pressure as another high-profile murder case heads to court.

22-year-old Tyler Robinson, accused of killing Charlie Kirk, is scheduled to make his first court appearance Tuesday afternoon. If prosecutors pursue the death penalty, it would be the fifth such case in Utah County in recent years — a trend that is putting immense strain on public resources, particularly the Public Defender’s Office.

“This is a huge burden,” said Nathan Evershed, a former prosecutor now working as a defense attorney. “There has been an uptick, and [these cases] are incredibly demanding on all areas and elements of the criminal justice system.”

snippet.title: Salt Lake Gallivan Center hosts world balance bike races for young children
snippet.description:
The Strider Cup World Championship returns to Salt Lake for the first time in eight years, filling the Gallivan Center with young children competing in a unique bike race.

The event has riders as young as 2-years-old in a race on a balance bike. Founder Ryan McFarland talked about what makes the races so much fun for children.

The balance bike is designed without pedals. The bike moves as the rider moves their body – often using their feet on the ground.

“They kind of Fred Flintstone it,” McFarland said. “They straddle the bike and run with their little legs.”

The bikes can be ridden by children as young as 2 years old.

“It’s on two wheels, so they’re learning how to balance and learn to truly handle a bike from a young, young age,” he said. “Later on in life, they’ll never need training wheels – they’ll be able to transition on to a regular pedal bike with ease, and years earlier.”

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/arc-salt-lake/salt-lake-gallivan-center-hosts-world-balance-bike-races-for-young-children

snippet.title: Thousands turn out for Turning Point's return to Utah 3 weeks after murder of Charlie Kirk
snippet.description:
Thousands of people gathered inside the Dee Glen Smith Spectrum at Utah State University for a Turning Point USA event that paid tribute to conservative commentator Charlie Kirk, drawing supporters from across the state.

The event, part of the “This is the Turning Point” tour, was hosted by conservative personality Alex Clark. It featured high-profile Republican figures and a message focused on continuing Kirk’s mission after the recent assassination of Charlie Kirk, which left many shaken.

“I see this empty chair, and it just does something to me, and I know it does something to you,” Tyler Bowyer, the COO for Turning Point USA, told the crowd, referencing Kirk’s absence.

snippet.title: No explosives found at Ben Lomond High School after bomb threat called to 911
snippet.description:
Ben Lomond High School has been fully cleared and deemed safe following a lockdown on Thursday that was initiated in response to a reported bomb threat.

After a thorough search, no explosives were found, and all students were safely reunited with their families, according to officers with the Ogden Police Department.

Capt. Tim Scott of the Ogden Police Department said a 911 call reported a bomb threat at Ben Lomond High School around 8:30 a.m. Police immediately began investigating the threat as an actual safety threat and not a hoax.

snippet.title: IN DEPTH: Utah County Attorney outlines evidence linking Tyler Robinson to Charlie Kirk killing
snippet.description:
OREM, Utah (KUTV) – Prosecutors have outlined their case against Tyler James Robinson, the 22-year-old Southern Utah native accused of killing conservative commentator Charlie Kirk during an event at Utah Valley University. 

A newly released 10-page charging document lays out how investigators believe Robinson carried out the shooting, attempted to cover it up and eventually turned himself in, all while allegedly sharing disturbing details with his roommate and parents.

Robinson was arrested following a 33-hour manhunt, but prosecutors now say it was his parents who ultimately led police to him. Utah County Attorney Jeff Gray said Robinson’s mother recognized the "person of interest" photo released by police and suspected it was her son.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/local/utah-county-attorney-outlines-evidence-linking-tyler-robinson-to-charlie-kirk-killing

snippet.title: High-powered rifle recovered believed to be weapon used to kill Charlie Kirk: FBI
snippet.description:
A high-powered rifle investigators claim was used in the shooting of political activist Charlie Kirk was recovered in a nearby wooded area of the Utah Valley University campus, according to the FBI.

During a press conference early Thursday morning, Utah Department of Public Safety Commissioner Beau Mason and FBI Special Agent in Charge Robert Bohls said investigators made a few breakthroughs since the fatal shooting.

Among those breakthroughs the recovery of the rifle. Commissioner Mason said the suspect jumped off the roof where the shooting took place and fled into the wooded area, dropping the rifle.

snippet.title: Video captures man setting Richfield home on fire
snippet.description:
Video captured a man allegedly setting his ex-wife's home on fire early this morning while she and her two minor children were asleep.

Delmar Ray Barney, 38, was arrested on two counts of attempted murder, a first-degree felony; three counts of aggravated arson, a first-degree felony; eight counts of aggravated assault, a third-degree felony; four counts of protective order violation, a class A misdemeanor; two counts of possession of a controlled substance, a class B misdemeanor; and one count of possession of drug paraphernalia, a class B misdemeanor.

His arrest comes after three other arson attempts.

snippet.title: Sundance Film Festival venue honors Robert Redford's Utah legacy
snippet.description:
From the film industry to the environment, Robert Redford made a great impact in Utah, most notably by bringing the Sundance Film Festival to Park City.

The Egyptian Theater played an important role in the Sundance Film Festival as it hosted some of the most famous independent films in the market. Immediately following the announcement of Robert Redford's death on Tuesday, the venue changed its sign as a tribute.

“Our theater got the ball rolling to change our marquee sign right away to honor Robert and his wonderful years here,” said Rebecca Jeanne Knowles, day manager at the Egyptian Theater.

snippet.title: Park City hosting World Downhill Skateboarding Championship Series
snippet.description:
What moves on four wheels and goes over 50 miles per hour? It’s not a car. Skateboarders will hit those speeds as the World Downhill Skateboarding Championship Series comes to Park City.

The four-day event runs September 25–28 and features freeriders, qualifying series racers, and championship tour competitors. Riders will test their control at high speeds while navigating sharp turns on Park City’s steep terrain.

Spectators can watch as athletes from around the world compete for a spot on the championship tour. Tickets are available for those who want to catch the races in person. 

Event promoter Selim Kemahli and World Gravity Sports Federation president Chris McBride say the series highlights both the skill and precision needed to master downhill skateboarding.

snippet.title: Police investigate Southern Utah homes after Charlie Kirk assassination suspect arrested
snippet.description:
Police investigated Southern Utah properties connected to the suspect in the assassination of Charlie Kirk, maintaining a constant presence at a family home and an apartment.

Tyler James Robinson, 22, was arrested in Washington City Thursday night and booked in the Utah County Jail on charges of aggravated murder, discharge of a firearm, and felony obstruction of justice, according to court documents.

A Washington City house, believed to be the suspect's family's home, has been frequented by officers and deputies since Robinson's arrest. There is also a gray Dodge parked outside the home, which could match the description of the suspect's vehicle provided by officials in a Friday press conference.

snippet.title: Daughter of Utah ex-judge acused of child sex crimes breaks silence
snippet.description:
A daughter of former Utah Judge Kevin Christensen, jailed for roughly six months on child sex crimes accusations, is breaking her silence and proclaiming she's broken up with members of her own family over the allegations.

“Instead of him being behind the bench, it's him in front, in handcuffs,” said the young woman, minutes after Christensen appeared in court again Thursday. “It's disappointing, and (I’m) angry, and sad. And honestly all the emotions."

She did not want to be identified, but others with knowledge of the family confirmed she was adopted by Christensen and his wife when she was a baby.

snippet.title: Redistricting chair: Legislature 'legally cannot' select map from independent commission
snippet.description:
The charged issue of political redistricting in Utah—for some a yawner, but an intense fight for others—moved closer to a measure of clarity on Wednesday with the latest meeting of a swiftly empaneled legislative Redistricting Committee.

"Every map we're going to show you today is in compliance with Prop. 4 standards," said Rep. Candice Pierucci, committee co-chair, harking to a 2018 initiative passed by voters, which established an independent commission to draw political maps.

The commission drew its lines, but the Republican-controlled Legislature made the commission an advisory body and approved its own map, sparking sharp criticism that lawmakers ignored the will of the people and were "gerrymandering."

snippet.title: Residents question if economy can sustain new St. George shopping complex
snippet.description:
A new shopping complex is underway in St. George, bringing national retailers to southern Utah, but some residents have raised questions about whether the region's economy and resources can sustain another mall.

The project, called "The Paseo," is under construction near 3000 East and Merrill Drive, just across from the Red Cliffs Utah Temple. City officials said the development will be unique from other shopping areas in the city, with an open-air design, multiple restaurants, and a movie theatre.

They hope that the new complex will complement, rather than compete with, existing shopping centers, like the Red Cliffs Mall.

FULL STORY: https://kutv.com/news/local/residents-question-if-economy-can-sustain-new-st-george-shopping-complex

snippet.title: UDOT seeks public input on widening Legacy Parkway to ease traffic congestion
snippet.description:
The Utah Department of Transportation wants to know what people think about widening Legacy Parkway between Farmington and Salt Lake City to three lanes in each direction.

They are proposing adding a lane northbound and southbound and getting rid of the median on Legacy Parkway, also known as State Route 67.

This would be approximately between 200 South in Farmington, or milepost 11.5, down to milepost 0 on I-215 in Salt Lake City.

snippet.description:

Crews with the Salt Lake City Fire Department responded to the scene on 1700 South at approximately 8:15 p.m. on Monday.

A caller said smoke and flames were coming from a roof.

snippet.title: Clinical trial shows positive treatment for Huntington's disease
snippet.description:
For those living with Huntington's Disease, there is now hope. A clinical trial in London showed positive results in treating the disease for the first time.

Morgan Pratt joined ARC Salt Lake to discuss the breakthrough and what it means for her and the Huntington's Disease community in Utah.

Also, this past weekend, the Huntington’s Disease Society of America Utah chapter hosted a 5K this past weekend to bring awareness. That event raised over $25,000 to help their organization.

For more info on how you can support go to: utah.hdsa.org

#huntingtonsdisease
